Contents.Text: ELEMENTS OF A CDSS ADVICE MENU
Advice menus are comprised of the following elements:
TYPICALLY present on an advice menu
1) Diagnosis or condition label-at the top of each advice menu.
2) Treatment. Empirical treatment as well as treatment for selected pathogens
is presented with links to antimicrobial quick orders unless stated otherwise.
In addition to the drug, dose, and route, each quick order text includes the
drug's approximate cost per day and coding for important drug properties of
note. Drugs clustered together are considered equivalent.
3) Help. At the top of each advice menu. There are links to a variety of
4) References. At the bottom on each advice menu. These are key references for
1) (Treatment) Alternative. Following the (preferred) Treatment section with
quick orders for common alternative antimicrobials. Antimicrobial listed under
each alternative header are equivalents among those listed. A broader selection
of medications can be accessed through the Need an alternative menu within the
help section. For some conditions we recommend alternative antimicrobials when
recommended drugs are not suitable for an individual patient. Unless otherwise
stated drugs clustered together under Alternatives are considered equivalent.
If none of the recommended or alternative drugs is suitable you can find more
drugs by clicking on the Need an alternative link at the top of the menu.
2) Consults. At the top of the menu, these are consultation requests pertinent
to the clinical problem addressed by the menu. Links to context-specific
consults can be found on advice menus, as appropriate. For example, the herpes
simplex encephalitis menu contains a link to a request for neurology consult.

provided for example. For some menus, supplemental resources have been

ENTERIC FEVER (INCLUDING TYPHOID AND PARATYPHOID FEVER)
Enteric fever is a systemic febrile illness caused by Salmonella enterica
serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A, B, or C. It is characterized by dramatic fever
and abdominal pain. Enteric fever typically occurs in patients who have traveled
to impoverished areas where the organisms are endemic, but can also be acquired
within the United States. Treatment is based on location of acquisition due to
increasing rates of fluoroquinolone resistance in Asia.

Epididymitis is inflammation of the epididymis and when testicles are involved
is referred to as epididymo-orchitis. Acute epididymitis is the most common
cause of scrotal pain in adults. Other features include scrotal erythema and
edema, pyuria, dysuria, thickened epididymis, swollen testis, and is usually
unilateral. It is primarily caused by infection but can also result from trauma
and autoimmune diseases. Testicular torsion should be ruled out before
treatment. Most cases in men aged 35 and older, those with recent urinary tract
instrumentation or surgery (e.g., prostate biopsy, vasectomy) are associated
with enteric Gram-negative rods. Most cases in men under age 35 are associated
with N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis. Resistant organisms are more likely if
the patient has been in the hospital for more than 48 hours or received a course
of antibiotics. There is increasing resistance in urinary pathogens to
A urine analysis, urine culture and urine nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)
should be performed in all cases of suspected epididymitis before starting
Patients at risk of sexually transmitted infections should be assessed for
treatment. Refer to the Urogenital section of the Antimicrobial CDSS for more
Patients with bacterial epididymitis treated with antibiotics should improve
within two or three days. If no improvement is noted, other causes of scrotal
pain and referral to a urologist should be considered.
Management should include bed rest, analgesics, and scrotal elevation. Older men
should have their residual urinary volume checked. If the residual volume is
elevated, the patient should be seen by a urologist as epididymitis is unlikely
to respond if the prostate is blocking the vas deferens.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX ESBL KPC ETC

Contents.Text: In some Gram-negative bacilli, potent bacterial enzymes have emerged that
inactive many newer broad-spectrum beta lactam drugs. These include extended-
lactamases, AmpC beta-lactamases and oxacillinases. These enzymes are most
common in strains of Acinetobacter, Citrobacter, Enterobacter, Escherichia coli,
Klebsiella, Proteus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Salmonella, and Serratia
marcescens. The enzymes can be latent under many circumstances. However, in
patients receiving beta lactam antibiotics, the enzymes can be expressed and
contribute to treatment failure. Because of this, and since the enzymes continue
to evolve, they are difficult to detect in clinical microbiology laboratories.
Bacteria carrying these enzymes are often also resistant to many other commonly
used antimicrobials, including trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, quinolones, and
others, through different mechanisms. Enterobacteriaceae, Pseudomonas and
Acinetobacter are increasingly resistant to all antimicrobials.
Clinicians must be aware that these enzymes may not be detected in all strains
that carry them. If a Gram-negative infection is not responding to therapy with
a beta lactam drug, consider adding or switching to a drug that is not a beta
lactam and appears active in the susceptibility report.
If a patient is suspected of having a Gram-negative infection and is likely to
be colonized with bacteria carrying these enzymes, empirical therapy with
alternative drugs that are not inactivated by them should be considered.
Risk factors for colonization or infection with resistant gram-negative bacilli
2. Central venous catheters and other indwelling tube and drains

Inactivate most cephalosporins, monobactams, and penicillins. Alternatives
Serine carbapenemases, metallo-beta-lactamases and oxacillinases alternative
Confer resistance to all beta-lactams. Most strains are also resistant to most
other antibiotic classes. Alternatives include aminoglycosides and colistin.
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and quinolones are non-beta-lactam alternative
antimicrobials, especially useful for IV to PO conversion. Gram negative bacilli
co-resistance to these antimicrobials is common however. Tigecycline (restricted
to ID) and ceftazidime-avibactam (non-formulary) are also potential options for
susceptible isolates. Infectious Diseases consultation is required for their

Contents.Text: Esophagitis is usually associated with non-infectious diseases like
gastroesophageal reflux disease, mucositis and pill-induced esophagitis.
Esophageal infection occurs primarily in immunosuppressed individuals (e.g.
chemotherapy, transplantation, HIV) and rarely in healthy individuals. The
majority of infectious esophagitis is caused by Candida albicans,
cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus. Aphthous ulceration of the
esophagus is common in HIV infection. HIV screening is recommneded.
Up-To-Date article: Herpes simplex virus infection of the esophagus

syndrome should be included in our system please contact us.

Asymptomatic carriage of Giardia is common in household contacts of people who

Contents.Text: Most acute disease is self-limited, and the virus does not cause chronic
disease. No specific antiviral therapy is available.
Patients who appear to be developing fulminant hepatitis, including those with
mental status changes should receive supportive treatment. Fulminant hepatitis
is suggested by increased prothrombin time, cholestasis, ascites, decreased
liver size, or decreasing serum albumin. Supportive treatment includes
maintenance of fluid and electrolyte balance, monitoring and possible correction
of coagulation defects, treatment of hepatic encephalopathy, and good nutrition
Prevention for persons with continuing high risk of disease
Vaccine should be offered to persons at high risk of hepatitis A infection: men
who have sex with men, travelers to endemic areas likely to be exposed, illegal
drug users, persons at occupational risk of disease, persons with chronic liver
Give Hepatitis A vaccine 1 ml IM x 2, separated by 6 to 12 months
Prevention for persons with a specific, defined exposure
Post-exposure prophylaxis should be offered to persons with substantial exposure
to hepatitis A. Specifically, persons exposed to acute hepatitis through
household or sexual contact, persons who attend or work in a day care center
with a recent case, or employee or patron of a restaurant with a food handler
with hepatitis. Post exposure prophylaxis must be given within 2 weeks of
exposure. Vaccine can be given at the same time as immune-globulin.
Give Hepatitis A vaccine 1 ml IM x 2, separated by 6 to 12 months

Contents.Text: Most acute hepatitis B disease is mild and self-limited. Patients who appear to
be developing fulminant hepatitis, including those with mental status changes
should receive supportive treatment. Fulminant hepatitis is suggested by
increased prothrombin time, cholestasis, ascites, decreased liver size, or
decreasing serum albumin. Supportive treatment includes maintenance of fluid
and electrolyte balance, monitoring and possible correction of coagulation
defects, treatment of hepatic encephalopathy, and good nutrition with a low-
protein diet. Antiviral therapy is not indicated. Gastroenterology consult
Antiviral therapy for chronic hepatitis B is a complicated, highly specialized
task. Consult with gastroenterology and infectious diseases.
Vaccinate persons at high risk of disease including men who have sex with men,
illegal drug users, and health care workers with substantial exposure to blood

Ocular herpes infection can be caused by either HSV-1 or HSV-2. The majority of
cases are caused by HSV-1. The recurrence rate of ocular herpes is 40% over a 5
year period, less than that of oral or genital herpes. Ocular herpes is a
major cause of blindness and typically presents as infection of the epithelium
of the cornea but can also rarely involve the stroma and endothelium.
Involvement of the stroma or endothelium requires treatment with topical
steroid and close monitoring. For these cases, start oral antiviral and consult
Antiviral prophylaxis is recommended for patients with multiple recurrences,
recurrent episodes with ulceration, recurrent inflammation with
scar/vascularization approaching visual axis, patients who have had keratoplasty
for HSV-related scarring/astigmatism, and patients who have had HSV keratitis
while on immunosuppressive therapy. Post-surgical prophylaxis is not discussed
here. Please consult ophthalmology for more information.
Infection prophylaxis for prevention of recurrence
Reassess need for prophylaxis every 12 months

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX HERPES SIMPLEX ESOPHAGITIS

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)

Contents.Text: HSV infection of the esophagus usually occurs in patients who are
immunocompromised, typically solid organ and bone marrow transplant
recipients.In healthy patients HSV esophagitis occurs occasionally,
usually in men under the age of 40.
Patients usually present with odynophagia and dysphagia.Fever
epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and heartburn are less frequent.
Some patients may have coexistent herpes labialis or oropharyngeal
ulcers.Diagnosis is usually established with an upper endoscopy.
Suggestive findings may also be seen during a barium swallow.
Spontaneous resolution usually occurs in immunocompetent patients after
one to two weeks. Patients may respond more quickly if treated with a
Treatment for mild to moderate disease
John Hopkin's Guides keyword: Herpes simplex virus
Up-to-Date article: Herpes simplex virus infection of the esophagitis

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX HOW TO FIND ALT ABX
DisplayText: How to find an alternative antimicrobial

Contents.Text: HOW TO FIND AN ALTERNATIVE ANTIMICROBIAL WITHIN THE CDSS
The CDSS has been developed locally with input from a broad, representative
group of clinicians. All antimicrobial recommendations within the Antimicrobial
CDSS are reviewed by a clinical pharmacist and an Infectious Diseases Medical
Specialist. Recommendations provided are based on local susceptibility patterns,
clinical evidence, local preferences, and national guidelines. In rare cases,
the recommended antimicrobials and listed alternatives may not be preferred for
the patient you are treating (e.g. isolate resistance, allergies, etc.). In
these cases, a broader set of alternative antimicrobials may be ordered through
the Antimicrobial CDSS. Like other antimicrobial orders in the CDSS,
antimicrobials ordered through the Alternative Antimicrobials menu do on require
a prior authorization or ID approval.
To access the Alternative Antimicrobials menu, navigate to the menu containing
antimicrobial recommendations for the infectious disease you are treating.
The Alternative Antimicrobial menu contains antimicrobial regimens that have
been deemed appropriate for use as alternatives to recommended antimicrobials by
the Antimicrobial P&T Subcommittee. If the list does not contain the preferred
antimicrobial, contact or consult Infectious Diseases.
The regimens provided in the Alternative Antimicrobial menu are not tailored for
a specific infectious disease. The dose, frequency, and duration must be changed
based on the infectious disease you are treating as well as for patient specific
factors. The usage of alternative antimicrobials are monitored by the
Antimicrobial CDSS team for appropriateness and to identify infectious diseases
At the top of the menu, select:
2 Help legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more
Then select- Alternative Antimicrobials to CDSS Recommendations
Select the reason an alternative antimicrobial is required then the Alternative

Contents.Text: How to find an alternative antimicrobial within the CDSS
The CDSS has been designed to offer antimicrobial prescribing advice quickly and
efficiently. Since inpatient and outpatient drugs are ordered differently, the
CDSS has both and inpatient and outpatient versions for prescribing.
The Antimicrobial CDSS is located within CPRS. When CPRS is open, click on the
Orders tab at the bottom left hand side of the CPRS window.
On the left-hand side of the "Orders" tab, click on the "Medicine Inpt Orders."
On the left-hand side of the "Orders" tab, click on the "Medicine Outpt Orders."
The main menu of the Antimicrobial CDSS contains links to categories of
infectious diseases based on syndrome/organ system (e.g. cardiovascular,
genitourinary, etc.), organisms (e.g. gram-positive bacteria, gram-negative
bacteria, viruses, etc.) and other special cases. To navigate to specific
infectious disease, select the category the infectious disease is associated
with. Within the category menu, select the specific infectious disease sub-menu
for recommendations, quick orders and pertinent resources (e.g., section-
specific consults, important drug properties, CDSS system help resources, etc.).
The Index is in the main menu at the top of the left-hand column under the
header Index of Antimicrobial CDSS content. The Index contains an alphabetized
list of Antimicrobial CDSS content. Find the infectious disease, organism or
other topic you are looking for by scrolling down the list. When you locate the
term you are looking for, click on it to be linked to the menu containing
specific recommendations, quick orders and pertinent resources.
Quick orders are preprogrammed with the usually recommended antimicrobial dose,
frequency and solution for the specific infectious disease.
Quick orders are not tailored to specific patient factors such as renal
insufficiency, comorbidities, contraindications, weight, allergies, etc. The
provider must assess every patient closely for these factors and modify
recommended antimicrobials if needed. To assist the provider, additional drug
information is provided within specific infectious diseases recommendation menus
and a link to more in depth information is provided at the top of these menus.
Alternatives to preferred antimicrobials quick orders are often provided in
recommendations, a broader selection of alternative antimicrobials is provided
in the Alternative Antimicrobial menu (see What if a Preferred Antimicrobial is

Acyclovir 10 mg/kg IV q8h ($$) [R,DI] for 14 to 21 days
Herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 is the leading cause of sporadic fatal
encephalitis worldwide and should be suspected in patients who have symptoms
unexplained by other causes. Typical symptoms include acute alteration of
consciousness for more than 24 hours, fever, new onset seizures and/or focal
neurologic deficits. Patients taking natalizumab are at increased risk of HSV
encephalitis. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to achieve resolution
of infection and symptoms. If diagnosis is not certain and there is little
likelihood of herniation, obtain cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample for HSV
polymerase chain reaction (PCR). MRI without contrast nearly always show
abnormal signs in patients with HSV encephalitis. Neurology and Infectious
Treatment, Initiate Immediately When HSV Encephalitis is Suspected
Up-to-Date Article: Herpes simplex virus type 1 encephalitis

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration advised that the serious
side effects associated with fluoroquinolone antibacterial drugs
generally outweigh the benefits for patients with acute sinusitis, acute
bronchitis, and uncomplicated urinary tract infections who have other
treatment options. For patients with these conditions, fluoroquinolones should
be reserved for those who do not have alternative treatment options.
An FDA safety review has shown that fluoroquinolones when used systemically
are associated with disabling and potentially permanent serious side effects
that can occur together. These side effects can involve the tendons,
muscles, joints, nerves, and central nervous system.
FDA identified cases of hypoglycemic coma, resulting in death in some
instances. Most pateints had risk factors for hypoglycemia such as older age,
diabetes, renal insufficiency, and concomitant use of hypoglycemic drugs,
especally sulfonylureas.FDA also identified reports of additional mental
health side effects, and requires that all fluoroquinolones include six
psychiatric adverse reactions (disturbance in attention, memory impairment,
stimulation, rare seizures, rare QT interval prolongation, and
tendinitis/tendon rupture. Six psychiatric adverse reactions
including disturbance in attention, memory impairment, delirium,
Hypoglycemia that can lead to coma, occuring more frequently in
the elderly and those with diabetes.

Trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole 1 DS tablet PO q12h ($) [R,DI]
Impetigo is a superficial skin infection that rarely causes systemic
symptoms. Ecthyma is a skin infection characterized by crusted sores
beneath which ulcers form. It is a deep form of impetigo, as the same
bacteria causing the infection are involved. Ecthyma causes deeper
erosions of the skin into the dermis.
Gram stain and culture of the pus or exudates from skin lesions of
impetigo and ecthyma are recommended to help identify whether
Staphylococcus aureus and/or beta-hemolytic Streptococcus is the cause.
Bullous and non-bullous impetigo can be treated with oral or topical
antimicrobials, but oral therapy is recommended for patients with
numerous lesions or in outbreaks affecting several people to help
decrease transmission of infection. Treatment for ecthyma should be an
Treatment for impetigo with few lesions
Treatment for ecthyma and for impetigo with numerous lesions or
whose symptoms have not responded to topical treatment
Mandell chapter: Cellulitis and subcutaneous tissue infections
Montravers P Curr Opin Infect Dis 2016, 29:131

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX IMPORTANT BETA-LACTAM ALLERGY FACTS
DisplayText: Important Beta-lactam Allergy Facts and Reaction History

Contents.Text: 1. 10% of patients report an allergy to penicillin.
2. Less than 1% of patients are truly allergic to penicillin.
3. 80% of patients who had an immediate allergic reaction (Type I,
Immunoglobulin E (IgE)-mediated) to penicillin lose sensitivity after 10
4. Cross-reactivity between penicillin and cephalosporins occurs in only 2% of
patients and most patients do not have clinically significant reactions.
- Locate documented reaction information within the Computerized Patient Record
> Reported reactions can be found in the Cover Sheet under Allergies/Adverse
Reactions. Double click on the specific reaction for more information,
including signs/symptoms and date of reaction.
> A reaction report can also be found here: Reports tab -> Clinical Reports -
- Determine beta-lactam medication history. A list of all locally prescribed
medications can be found here: Reports tab -> Clinical Reports -> Pharmacy ->
- Interview the patient or family for details about the reaction. Questions to
> What medication were you taking when the reaction occurred? DO NOT accept
Penicillin or Cephalosporin as an allergy, ensure specific offending
> How long after taking the medication did the reaction occur? Immediate
reactions typically occur within 1 hour and up to 72 hours after
administration. Delayed reactions occur after 72 hours.
> How long ago did the reaction occur? Did it occur over 10 years ago?
> What kind of reaction occurred? Did the reaction require medical attention?

Contents.Item: ORZ SET ABX VANCO+RIFAMP 300MG PO Q8H
Contents.DisplayText: VANCO 15MG/KG IV Q12H RIFAMPIN 300 MG PO Q8H
Contents.Text: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV q12h ($) [R] <AND> rifampin 300 mg PO/NG q8h ($)
Most infections are associated with Staphylococcus aureus and coagulase-negative
staphylococci.Many of these staphylococci are resistant to methicillin, so
initial empiric therapy with vancomycin is required. Consultation with
Infectious Diseases is encouraged for patients with severe allergies to
vancomycin or for those who have vancomycin-resistant infections.
At least 3 blood cultures should be drawn prior to the initiation of empirical
antimicrobial. Modify antimicrobial regimen and narrow coverage based on results
of culture and susceptibility tests Infectious Disease and Cardiothoracic
Device removal is necessary for cure in most cases.However, it may be
difficult depending on the nature of the device and specific clinical
circumstances.Device removal should be discussed with Cardiology, Infectious
If the device removal is not possible add rifampin.
Duration of therapy should be determined in concert with Cardiology, Infectious
Empiric treatment in cases where device removal is planned
Empiric treatment in cases where surgery cannot be performed
For hemodynamically unstable patients, add gentamicin to one of the above

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)

Contents.Text: Early treatment as alternative to chemoprophylaxis:
In most cases, if a person is suspected of having been exposed to influenza,
early treatment should signs or symptoms develop is preferred rather than
The provider should explain the early signs and symptoms of influenza to the
patient and advise the patient to immediately contact a health care provider
for evaluation and possible early treatment if these symptoms or signs
develop. Influenza-like symptoms or signs include fever, cough, sore throat,
runny or stuffy nose, body aches, headache, chills, fatigue, vomiting, and
diarrhea. Influenza can present without fever.
Health care providers should use clinical judgment regarding situations where
early recognition of illness and treatment might be an appropriate
Early treatment alternative or chemoprophylaxis may be considered:
*Persons who are part of a high-risk group and are household or close
contacts of someone with influenza-like illness
*Atypical situations (such as case clusters). Contact state health department
Zanamivir is not recommended for patients with chronic respiratory disease such
as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. These patients may have
bronchospasm with zanamivir. If zanamivir must be used, and patients are using
an inhaled bronchodilator, zanamivir should be taken just after the
*For control of outbreaks in institutional settings (long-term care

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX INFLUENZA EGG ALLERGY ACIP
DisplayText: Information on Influenza Vaccinations for patients with egg allergies

Contents.Text: Influenza Vaccine for Patients with Egg Allergies
Previously the ACIP had recommended that persons with serious egg allergies
receive the egg-free influenza vaccine- i.e FluBlok. In 2016-2017 the ACIP
changed the recommendation for persons with egg-allergies to state that
all persons should receive any formulation of age-appropriate flu vaccine
This change was based on data from large studies of greater than 4000 egg
allergic patients with 500 of them having severe egg allergy who received
the influenza vaccine with no anaphylactic reactions. Egg-allergic patients
should be monitored just like everyone else for 15 minutes after influenza
Grohskopf LA, MMWR Recommendations and Reports 2021, 70(5):1-28
Up-to-date online: Influenza vaccination in individuals with egg allergy

Epididymitis is inflammation of the epididymis and when testicles are involved
is referred to as epididymo-orchitis. Acute epididymitis is the most common
cause of scrotal pain in adults. Other features include scrotal erythema and
edema, pyuria, dysuria, thickened epididymis, swollen testis, and is usually
unilateral. It is primarily caused by infection but can also result from trauma
and autoimmune diseases. Testicular torsion should be ruled out before
treatment. Most cases in men aged 35 and older, those with recent urinary tract
instrumentation or surgery (e.g., prostate biopsy, vasectomy) are associated
with enteric Gram-negative rods. Most cases in men under age 35 are associated
with N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis. Resistant organisms are more likely if
the patient has been in the hospital for more than 48 hours or received a course
of antibiotics. There is increasing resistance in urinary pathogens to
A urine analysis, urine culture and urine nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)
should be performed in all cases of suspected epididymitis before starting
Patients at risk of sexually transmitted infections should be assessed for
treatment. Refer to the Urogenital section of the Antimicrobial CDSS for more
Patients with bacterial epididymitis treated with antibiotics should improve
within two or three days. If no improvement is noted, other causes of scrotal
pain and referral to a urologist should be considered.
Management should include bed rest, analgesics, and scrotal elevation. Older men
should have their residual urinary volume checked. If the residual volume is
elevated, the patient should be seen by a urologist as epididymitis is unlikely
to respond if the prostate is blocking the vas deferens.
Empirical treatment in men who practice insertive anal intercourse
Empirical treatment in men who do not practice insertive anal intercourse

Serological testing for amoebiasis should be obtained in all patients with
suspected amebic liver abscess. Multiple sets of anaerobic and aerobic blood
cultures should also be obtained prior to starting antibiotics to exclude
pyogenic liver abscess, which is a much more common cause of liver abscess.
Serologic testing can be negative in a small number of patients with acute
presentation (symptoms <2 weeks). Repeat serology is usually positive. If repeat
serological testing is negative for amoebiasis or patient does not respond to
treatment of amebic liver abscess, patient should have further diagnostic
testing completed to exclude pyogenic liver abscess.
Drainage of amebic liver abscess should be considered in patients with large
Due to complicated treatment and follow up, Infectious Diseases consultation
is recommended in all patients with liver abscess.
Treatment of patients with confirmed or suspected amebic liver abscess (obtain
blood cultures prior to starting in suspected cases)
Paromomycin is nonformulary and must be ordered by Infectious Diseases.
Mandell chapter: Infections of the Liver and Biliary System
Solomkin et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2010, 50:133-64

Liver abscess should be suspected in all patients with fever, leukocytosis, and
a space-occupying liver lesion. Liver abscesses fall broadly into two
categories: pyogenic and amebic. In the United States, pyogenic liver abscess is
much more common. Amebic liver abscess occurs almost exclusively in travelers
and immigrants. If amebic liver abscess is suspected, select the link below.
Due to complicated treatment and follow up, Infectious Diseases consultation is
recommended in patients with pyogenic liver abscess.
A typical course for pyogenic liver abscess is 4 to 6 weeks.

all cases.Obtain samples for gram stain and culture from fine needle
aspiration whenever possible.Sputum culture is less helpful because it will be
contaminated with upper respiratory flora.Classically, lung abscess is a
complication of mixed anaerobic and aerobic pulmonary infection. The initial
infection may or may not be clinically apparent.Malaise, weight loss, fever,
chills, and malodorous sputum typically develop over a period of weeks.
Cavitation and/or abscess can occur in cases of pneumonia from a single
pathogen, commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Antimicrobial treatment should be directed against the specific pathogen.
Treat for 6 to 8 weeks and adjust treatment based on clinical response.Oral

Lyme disease results from the transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi from an
Ixodes spp. tick bite. Patients who display signs of illness or fever within 30
days of removing an attached tick should be evaluated for tick-borne illness.
In the upper Midwest these are Lyme disease, human anaplasmosis, babesiosis, and
Powassan virus disease. Patients who have been bitten by an Ixodes spp. tick
(deer tick) but who do not display signs or symptoms of infection should not
Prophylactic antimicrobial treatment may be beneficial in certain patients who
have been bitten while in endemic areas.
Except for erythema migrans, Lyme disease is a complicated, difficult disease to
diagnose and treat. Infectious Diseases consultation is strongly encouraged.
Mandell Chapter: Lyme Disease (Lyme Borreliosis) Due to Borrelia burgdorferi

and overwhelming infection with encapsulated bacteria. Streptococcus
pneumoniae is the most common cause of fulminant sepsis in patients with
impaired splenic function, followed by Haemophilus influenzae and Neisseria
If fever develops in an asplenic patient, immediate administration of an
antimicrobial agent is indicated, because fever can be the initial
manifestation of a fulminant infection and prompt administration of an
antimicrobial agent may prevent the development of clinical sepsis.

Contents.Text: Mediastinitis occurs after cardiothoracic procedures or less commonly after
esophageal perforation.Rarely, infectious diseases of the head, neck or thorax
spread into the mediastinum.Surgical drainage and antimicrobial therapy are
both essential.Specific management depends on the source of infection.Obtain
aerobic and anaerobic cultures in all cases.
Inhalational anthrax (due to Bacillus anthracis) typically presents as
mediastinitis with cough productive of hemorrhagic secretions.This disease
should be considered in a patient without typical risk factors for mediastinitis
or in the setting of suspected or confirmed bioterrorism.If anthrax is
suspected, page the Infectious Diseases service.
Mixed aerobic/anaerobic infection is often present.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX MICROGUIDE MOBILE APP INSTRUCTIONS

Contents.Text: DIRECTIONS TO INSTALL MICROGUIDE ON MOBILE DEVICE
Within the Apple or Google app store on your mobile device, search for the term
"MicroGuide" and download the app. When opening the app, you will be prompted to
submit information about yourself and institution (this is for tracking usage of
the system by CDSS personal). Select the Minneapolis VA Health Care System as
your institution. You will then be prompted to download the Minneapolis VA
Health Care System CDSS specific guide content.

Paxlovid (nirmatrelvir-ritonavir) is available via FDA Emergency Use
Authorization (EUA) for treating patients that meet specific criteria. Paxlovid
is not an FDA approved drug.
Note: See below for inclusion criteria. Does not require ID approval.
ID available to discuss if needed.
Inclusion Criteria, ALL the following criteria must be met for a patient to
1) Patient has tested positive for COVID-19
2) Patient is not hospitalized due to COVID-19. Note: patient may be
4) Administration will begin within 5 days of symptom onset.
5) Patient does not have known hypersensitivity to Paxlovid or components.
Contraindications, NONE of the following must be met for patient to receive:
3) History of clinically significant hypersensitivity reactions to the active
ingredients (nirmatrelvir or ritonavir) or any other components.
4) Co-administration with drugs highly dependent on CYP3A for clearance and for
which elevated concentrations are associated with serious and/or
5) Co-administration with potent CYP3A inducers where significantly reduced
nirmatrelvir or ritonavir plasma concentrations may be associated with the
potential for loss of virologic response and possible resistance.
1) The concomitant use of PAXLOVID and certain other drugs may result in
potentially significant drug interactions. Consult the full prescribing
information prior to and during treatment for potential drug interactions.
2) Hepatotoxicity: Hepatic transaminase elevations, clinical hepatitis, and
jaundice have occurred in patients receiving ritonavir.
3) HIV-1 Drug Resistance: PAXLOVID use may lead to a risk of HIV-1 developing
resistance to HIV protease inhibitors in individuals with uncontrolled or
If all above criteria above are met and there are no contraindications, place
*Dose reduction for moderate renal impairment (eGFR =30 to <60 mL/min): 150 mg

both tablets taken together twice daily for 5 days.
*Patients treated with this drug should continue to self-isolate and use

personal items, clean and disinfect "high touch" surfaces, and frequent
6) Patient must be able to take PO and swallow tablets whole

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NOT BENEFITED PHARYNGITIS

Contents.Text: Acute pharyngitis is common, accounting for 2 percent of all
ambulatory visits in the United States.The major treatable pathogen, group
A streptococcus (GAS), is the cause of pharyngitis in only approximately 10
percent of adults who seek medical care.The vast majority of patients
receive presumptive antibiotic therapy for pharyngitis which in most cases is
unnecessary and results in adverse effects including death, increases costs,
and adds to pressure on antimicrobial resistance.Typical causes of
pharyngitis include viruses in about , beta-hemolytic streptococci other
than group A in 18%, Mycoplasma pneumoniae in 10%, Chlamydophila pneumoniae
in 8%, Group A streptococci in 5%, and no microbe identified in 1/3.
Rheumatic fever is rare in the United States, especially in adults, so
that some authorities recommend no treatment even if GAS is a potential cause
of pharyngitis. Others feel it is important to detect GASsince antibiotic
therapy can slightly shorten the acute illness, prevent acute rheumatic fever
and possibly prevent suppurative sequelae.Other potential causes of
pharyngitis that should be considered and diagnosed if likely include
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) mononucleosis, primary HIV infection, influenza,
gonococcal pharyngitis, diphtheria, and suppurative pharyngeal infections.
The Centor criteria are used to predict whether GAS pharyngitis is present.
If three or four of these criteria are met, the positive predictive value is
40 to 60 percent.If fewer than three criteria are present, the likelihood
GAS is causing pharyngitis is less than 20 percent.If 3 or > Centor criteria
are met, obtain a throat culture for group A streptococcus.Treat
empirically for GAS if the patient has severe symptoms or treat later for GAS
if the throat culture is positive.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NOT BENEFITTED BACTERIURIA

Contents.Text: Treatment of Candida Urinary Tract Infections
Asymptomatic bacteriuria (>= 100,000 bacteria per ml of urine) is common in
middle aged and older people, especially those who have chronic medical
conditions. Pyuria is common in persons with bacteriuria and individuals with
indwelling catheters in place. By itself, the presence of pyuria is not
sufficient to diagnose bacteriuria, and the presence or absence of pyuria does
not differentiate symptomatic from asymptomatic urinary infection. Candiduria is
less common than bacteriuria, but the implications of candiduria are similar to
Many studies, including randomized clinical trials have shown that
treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria and candiduria, with or without pyuria is
of no benefit, except in certain well-defined circumstances. Antimicrobial
therapy is always accompanied by risk of harms, including drug reactions,
Clostridium difficile colitis, anaphylaxis and death. Except in circumstances
specified below, it is best to not order urinalysis or urine culture in
asymptomatic persons. If bacteriuria, candiduria or pyuria is discovered in an
asymptomatic person for some reason, antimicrobial therapy should not be given
Pregnant women or patients undergoing urological procedures with bacteriuria
Patients undergoing urological procedures or neutropenic patients with
Pappas et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2016, 62.409
Nicolle et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2005, 40:643

CONDITIONS NOT BENEFITTED BY ANTIMICROBIAL THERAPY
Several common conditions associated with inflammation or
microorganisms do not benefit from antibiotic therapy in most or all cases.
Yet, antimicrobials are frequently prescribed for these conditions leading to
unnecessary toxicity and costs, rare deaths, and the relentless increase in
antimicrobial resistance. Please review these conditions and do not give
antimicrobials for these conditions unless there are extraordinary
circumstances that make your situation different. If you have any questions,
please contact the infectious disease physician on call.

Antimicrobials are not indicated for uncomplicated pancreatitis.
In cases of necrotizing pancreatitis without infection, antimicrobial
prophylaxis does not improve patient outcomes. Antimicrobials increase the risk
of fungal superinfection and should not be used.
Antimicrobials are indicated for cases with pancreatic abscess, infected
pancreatic pseudocyst, or infected necrotic pancreas (phlegmon). The diagnosis
of infection can be difficult and may require aspiration. Consultation with
Gastroenterology and/or Infectious Diseases is encouraged.
In cases with necrosis, aspirate necrotic material (fine needle under CT or
ultrasound guidance) for smear and culture. Uninfected cases should not receive

Infection of salivary tissue is a relatively common disease. It is usually
caused by a stone in the parotid duct, dehydration, or a viral infection.
Sialolithiasis in elderly patients often leads to ductal obstruction and
secondary infection. Other predisposing factors for ductal occlusion include
dehydration, anticholinergic medications such as tricyclics and diphenhydramine,
general disability and trauma. Once culture results are available adjust
antimicrobial therapy based on specific etiologic organism.
For more information click on the link below

Suppurative Parotitis or Chronic Bacterial Parotitis Exacerbation Empiric
If MRSA suspected or alternative to above:
Suspect mumps parotitis if there is fever, malaise, earache and bilateral tender
swelling of the parotid glands. For mumps parotitis treat with warm compresses
and analgesics and maintain good hydration to prevent secondary bacterial
infection. Other viral causes of parotitis include influenza and enteroviruses.
Wilson et al., Am Fam Physician. 2014, 89(11)882-888

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX PAROTITIS MORE INFORMATION

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)
Contents.Text: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)
Suppurative Parotitis. Acute bacterial parotitis affects primarily elderly,
malnourished, dehydrated or post-operative patients. Symptoms include fever,
toxicity, and tender swelling along the mandible with purulent drainage from the
parotid duct. Suppurative parotitis is usually unilateral whereas viral
parotitis is usually bilateral. Pain is intense and aggressive, analgesic
therapy is required. Progression of infection may lead to massive swelling of
the neck, respiratory obstruction, septicemia and osteomyelitis of adjacent
facial bones. Empiric antibiotics are required for coverage of Staphylococcus
aureus if bacterial, and surgical drainage is usually necessary.
Chronic Parotitis. Parotitis is recurrent with intermittent acute exacerbations.
Chronic, low-grade bacterial infection results in functional destruction of the
salivary gland. It may be confused with Sjogren's syndrome, a noninfectious
illness. Therapy includes systemic antibiotics. Parotidectomy may eventually be
required for patients with long-standing infection.
Viral Parotitis. Mumps parotitis is characterized by the rapid, painful swelling
of one or both parotid glands within 2 to 3 weeks after exposure to the mumps
virus. Mumps usually involves both parotid glands whereas bacterial parotitis is
unilateral. Other viral causes of parotitis include influenza and enteroviruses.
Mumps parotitis usually resolves spontaneously in 5 to 10 days. Provide
symptomatic relief of pain and fever and maintain hydration to prevent secondary
Wilson et al., Am Fam Physician. 2014, 89(11)882-888
Mandell chapter:Principles and Practice of Infectious Diseases

> Perform in an ICU or similar setting.

Peritonitis associated with peritoneal dialysis usually presents with abdominal
pain, fever, nausea or vomiting, and cloudy effluent. The leukocyte
concentration is greater than 100 cells/microliter of dialysate, with more than
Obtain Gram stain, culture, and cell count with differential of dialysate before
antimicrobials are given. Nephrology consultation is essential. If cultures
show Gram-negative or mixed bacterial infection, a gastrointestinal tract
infectious source is more likely. Gram-positive organisms like staphylococci
usually result from external contamination. Fungal peritonitis is rare and
**Antimicrobial recommendations are for empirical therapy only. Regimens should
be tailored according to patient response and microbiology results in
consultation with Nephrology and/or Infectious Diseases for more information.
To prevent catheter occlusion by turbid dialysate, add 1,000 units of heparin
per dialysis bag each day until one day after the dialysate is clear.
If vancomycin is used, trough serum concentrations should be kept above 15
mcg/ml to ensure adequate intraperitoneal levels. Usually vancomycin must be
given every 3 to 7 days. Contact Nephrology and/or Pharmacy for more
Antifungal prophylaxis may be used for the duration of antimicrobial therapy to
possibly reduce the risk of fungal peritonitis.
Duration of therapy depends on the pathogen identified. Treat staphylococcal and
streptococcal infections for 2 weeks and all other gram-positive infections for
3 weeks. In patients who have Staphylococcus isolated and had a previous
All antimicrobials below are administered via peritoneal dialysate bag over 6

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) refers to bacterial infection of the upper
female reproductive tract. Likely bacterial pathogens include Neisseria
gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, anaerobes, enteric Gram-negative rods, and
Streptococcus agalactiae. PID should be considered in sexually active women
with pelvic tenderness and signs of lower genital tract inflammation. Signs and
symptoms may be mild or non-specific, and providers should have a low threshold
to initiate treatment. All women who are diagnosed with acute PID should be
tested for N. gonorrohoeae, C. trachomatis, and HIV. Male sex partners of
patients with PID should be examined and treated (see below) if they had sexual
contact within the 60 days before onset of the patient's symptoms.
Judge severity of infection based on clinical signs and symptoms, including
blood pressure, pulse, mental status, and degree of fever.

Contents.Text: Indications for primary prophylaxis of P. jirovecii include:
1) HIV/AIDS patients with CD4 count <200 cells/microliter
2) Hematopoietic or organ transplantation patients during immunosuppression
3) Patients receiving Alemtuzumab, temozolomide or fludarabine
4) Patients receiving >/= 20mg equivalent of prednisone per day for over 1 month
5) Patients with acute lymphocytic leukemia, rheumatologic disease receiving
immunosuppressive therapy and certain primary immunodeficiencies (e.g. severe
combined immunodeficiency, idiopathic CD4 T-lymphocytopenia, hyper-IgM
Dose and duration of prophylaxis varies with the indication. Please contact
Infectious Diseases or Hematology/Oncology for more information.
Prophylaxis should be discontinued when host defenses are restored. In persons
with AIDS on highly active antiretroviral therapy, Prophylaxis should be
discontinued when the CD4 cell concentrations remain over 200 cells/microliter
for 3 to 6 months in patients, except that prophylaxis should be continued for
life in those who have had P. jirovecii disease.

Contents.Text: Treatment of CNS Infected Intravascular Catheters
BLOOD CULTURE POSITIVE FOR COAGULASE NEGATIVE STAPHYLOCOCCI (CNS)
CNS are the most common contaminants isolated from blood cultures. When CNS
isolated from blood cultures represent true bacteremia, the blood is usually
obtained from a patient with plastic or metal in the body. The most common
source of coagulase negative staphylococcal bacteremia is an infected
When CNS are isolated from blood, the physician should carefully assess the
patient to decide whether the isolation represents disease or colonization.
Colonization is more likely if a single bottle is positive or both bottles from
a single blood draw are positive. If multiple bottles are positive from separate
blood draws, it is more likely that the isolates reflect disease or colonization
of an intravascular device. Isolates from contaminated bottles often take
several days to become positive. If the patient has risk factors for true
coagulase negative staphylococcal bacteremia, catheter-related blood stream
infection and/or the patient is severely ill, antimicrobials should be given
(see below). If there is a plastic or metal prosthesis in the body, the
physician should evaluate the site for possible infection. If the isolates are
likely to represent contamination and the patient does not seem ill with CNS,
antimicrobial therapy would not be helpful and should not be given.
Mandell chapter: Staphylococcus epidermis and Other Coagulase-Negative
Mermel et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2009, 49

Features of pyelonephritis include fever/other signs of systemic infection,
flank pain, costovertebral tenderness, and pelvic or perianal pain in men. Most
cases are caused by Escherichia coli. Resistant organisms, such as Enterococcus
and Pseudomonas, are more likely if the patient is elderly, has been in the
hospital for more than 48 hours, or received a course of antibiotics.
Obtain a urine culture, urine Gram-stain, and blood culture immediately to guide
Drugs active against enterococci (ampicillin, piperacillin) or staphylococci
needn't be used if Gram-negative bacilli predominate on the smear. Broad
spectrum antimicrobials are needed if patient is at risk of having a multi-drug
Judge severity of infection based on clinical signs and symptoms, including
blood pressure, pulse, mental status, white blood count, and degree of fever.
Oral regimens are preferred over IV if severity is mild or moderate and patient
can tolerate oral antibiotics. In patients with severe or persistent disease,
new renal failure, or suspected urinary obstruction, obtain a renal ultrasound
to rule out obstruction or other complicating condition. Consult urology if
When patients who require paraenteral therapy are afebrile, clinically stable,
and can take oral medication, convert to oral therapy based on the
identification and susceptibility of the isolate.
Treat for 7 to 14 days. In patients with a mild infection and a quick clinical
response, 7 days of treatment may be adequate. A longer duration may be required
in severe infection, resistant organisms, presence of obstruction, underlying
renal disease, immunosuppression, neurologic or structural abnormality, and men
in some cases. A 7-day course of ciprofloxacin has been shown to be as effective
History of Pseudomonas or ESBL isolate
History of MRSA, add to intravenous therapy above
Enterobacteria including E. coli, klebsiella, and proteus
Alternative or isolate resistant to preferred antimicrobials:
*Avoid trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole in the first and third trimesters
S. aureus is an uncommon urinary tract pathogen and presence in the urine may be
due to hematogenous seeding from another site. Blood cultures are indicated to
rule out bacteremia in patients who have S. aureus isolated from the urine.
Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.

Contents.Text: Assess for favorable clinical response indicated by improvement in one or more
of the following: fever, mental status, appetite, ability to eat, oxygenation,
blood pressure, pulse, leukopenia.If the patient has improved, continue to
If the patient has not improved, consider the following
1. The patient has pneumonia with a pathogen resistant to empirical
2. The patient does not have bacterial pneumonia.Consider alternative
diagnoses including pulmonary edema, atelectasis, pulmonary embolus, ARDS,
pulmonary hemorrhage, underlying disease, and neoplasm.
3. The patient has infectious disease outside the lungs.
4. The patient has one or more complications of pneumonia (e.g., empyema, lung
5. The patient has an adverse drug event
Infectious Disease or Pulmonary consult is strongly encouraged for patients who
do not respond to initial therapy.If bacterial pneumonia is still considered
Decide whether a likely pathogen has been identified from respiratory secretions
or blood.The clinician must decide whether any organisms identified on smear
or culture of respiratory tract secretions reflect disease, colonization, or
contamination based on clinical and microbiological information.
The quality of a respiratory secretion sample must be evaluated.Sputum samples
with fewer than 25 polymorphonuclear leukocytes per high power field (hpf) are
unlikely to be from a site of bacterial infection unless the patient is
profoundly neutropenic.Sputum samples with more than 10 epithelial cells/hpf
are likely to be contaminated with upper respiratory tract secretions.
In cases of bacterial pneumonia, a gram stain of a high quality respiratory
tract secretion usually contains 3+ or 4+ of bacteria with morphology and
staining characteristics consistent with the pathogen.Culture of the
respiratory tract secretion indicates the species and susceptibilities of the
Decide whether to continue, modify, or discontinue antimicrobials.If an
organism likely to be a respiratory pathogen is isolated from a patient thought
to have bacterial pneumonia, adjust therapy if necessary to treat this pathogen.
If the patient does not have convincing evidence for bacterial pneumonia and/or
a likely pathogen has not been isolated from respiratory secretions then stop

REACTIVATION OF PRIMARY INFECTION (ZOSTER OR SHINGLES)
Zoster represents reactivation of varicella-zoster virus. After primary
infection, virus remains latent in the sensory dorsal root ganglia.
Reactivation syndrome is characterized by painful, unilateral, vesicular,
Vaccinate all adults greater than or equal to 50 years of age with the
recombinant zoster vaccine regardless of past episode or receipt of the live
Give recombinant zoster vaccine x2, 2nd dose 2-6 months after the first
Treatment is not beneficial, none is recommended.
Treatment with antivirals can shorten duration of pain and rash in patients over
50 years old. Treatment must be started within 72 hours of onset.
There is evidence that addition of corticosteroids to antiviral
therapy decreases pain and duration of rash and improves quality of life
modestly during the acute shingles episode. Corticosteroids do not decrease the
incidence of post-herpetic neuralgia. Some authorities recommend addition of
corticosteroid therapy to antiviral therapy for patients over age 50 years.
Corticosteroids are not recommended for patients at greater risk for steroid
toxicities (e.g., insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, hypertension, peptic
ulcer disease) or for immunocompromised patients.
Immunocompromised patients at increased risk for complications of VZV disease
include: patients with malignancy, current immunosuppressive therapy, or HIV
infection. Treatment with antivirals shortens duration of symptoms and reduces
incidence of complications. In immunocompromised patients, treatment is
recommended to be started at any point during an active infection.

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX RECALCITRANT ACNE AND ROSACEA

Contents.Text: Rosacea is an inflammatory skin condition resulting in erythema and
telangiectasia of nose, cheeks, eyelids, and forehead. It typically occurs in
mid-life and the etiology is unknown. Erythematous rosacea is the early stage of
the disease and usually manifests with flushing reactions and persistently
erythematous skin. Late-stage disease is known as papulopustular rosace.
Symptoms include papular, pustular, cysts and nodules. Severe disease results in
The goal of treatment is control of symptoms, not cure. General treatment
measures include avoiding triggers (e.g. spicy food, alcohol), skin care (e.g.
moisturizing, gentle cleansing, avoiding topical irritants) and using sun
screen. Medical treatment includes topical agents as first line therapy and oral
**FOR DERMATOLOGY USE ONLY, REQUIRES DERMATOLOGY CONSULT PRIOR TO TREATMENT**

SECONDARY PERITONITIS, INTRAABDOMINAL ABSCESS, INTRAPERITONEAL ABSCESS
Secondary peritonitis occurs after spillage of colonic flora into the peritoneum
due to ruptured viscus, perforated appendicitis, gastrointestinal trauma, or
Intraperitoneal or intraabdominal abscess can complicate secondary or primary
peritonitis. Abscess location is generally related to primary disease site.
CT or US-guided percutaneous or surgical drainage should be considered in all
cases for diagnostic confirmation, microbiologic evaluation, and therapy.
After adequate drainage, 4 days of antibiotic coverage is indicated, with
duration in part based on resolution of fever, leukocytosis, ileus severity of
infection, and additional indicators of clinical response. Inadequately drained
abscess with residual fluid may require prolonged therapy with follow-up imaging

Trichomonas Vaginitis, Urethritis and Male Sex Partners
that could result in HIV exposure. Recommendation is for the provider to
discuss with the patient Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) to reduce risk of
HIV acquisition.If the patient is interested, the provider should place a
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (or PrEP) is a way for people who do not have
HIV but who are at high risk of getting HIV to prevent HIV infection by
taking a pill every day. When someone is exposed to HIV through sex or
injection drug use, these medicines can work to keep the virus from
When taken daily, PrEP is highly effective for preventing HIV. Studies
have shown that PrEP reduces the risk of getting HIV from sex by about
99% when taken daily. PrEP is much less effective if not taken consistently.
As PrEP only protects against HIV, condoms are important for the protection
against other STIs. Condoms are also an important prevention strategy
if PrEP is not taken consistently.

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX SPLENECTOMY DAILY ANTIBIOTICS

Contents.Text: Following a splenectomy there is considerably increased risk of developing
septicemia from invasive encapsulated organisms, namely Streptococcus pneumonia,
Haemophilus inluenza type b and meningococcus. Key measures to prevent
such infections include education, vaccination, prophylactic antimicrobial
therapy in selected patients, and early empirical therapy for febrile
epsisodes. It is critically important to educate patients regarding the
lifelong risk of postsplenectomy sepsis, the importance of vaccinations,
and the need for urgent action in response to a febrile episode.
Management of an Episode of Fever in an Asplenic Patient
Ideally splenectomy vaccinations should be given 10 to 12 weeks before
elective splenectomy.Where this is not possible they can be given up to
two weeks before or at least two weeks post-splenectomy.
Use of Antibiotic Prophylaxis for Asplenia:
Use of antibiotic prophylaxis, in addition to vaccination, further reduces
the risk of infection and poor outcomes.
Daily Antibiotic Prophylaxis: (in addition to emergency supply)
Emergency Supply Empiric Abx for Fever or Other Signs of Systemic Infection:
See CDSS immunization section to order, if needed.

SBP is infection of the peritoneal cavity in the absence of apparent trauma or
other obvious cause. SBP occurs primarily in people with end-stage liver disease
and ascites. The diagnosis is made when a peritoneal fluid sample has >/= 250
polymorphonuclear leukocyte cells per microliter, or when bacterial pathogens
Long-term SBP prophylaxis is indicated for patients who experience a first
episode of SBP. Short-term SBP prophylaxis is indicated for patients with
variceal bleeding, or for patients who have low-protein refractory ascites (<1
gm albumin/dl ascitic fluid). Some give long-term antimicrobials to patients
with low-protein refractory ascites. Consult Gastroenterology for more

Contents.Text: Mupirocin 2% ointment topically BID ($) [M] <AND> chlorhexidine 4% liquid
From 10% to 40% of adults are colonized with Staphylococcus aureus, and the
anterior nares is the most common site of colonization. The great majority of
people never have disease with S. aureus, but a tiny fraction of people develop
clinical infections with the S. aureus that has colonized their skin or anterior
nares. Steps to decolonize the skin and anterior nares can transiently diminish
or eradicate S. aureus colonization and can prevent post-operative wound
infection in certain high-risk circumstances. For people who have other forms
of recurrent S. aureus disease, not associated with an operation, results with
decolonization have been disappointing, and decolonization is not routinely
recommended. Colonization typically reappears in most patients within a few
days or weeks after decolonization has been attempted. Clinicians occasionlly
wish to attempt decolonization for patients with frequent, troublesome
recurrences. The procedure here is one of several that have been studied, but
none have been particularly effective over the long run.
Consultation with Infectious Diseases is recommended.

Stasis dermatitis is a common condition that is often confused with
bacterial cellulitis. Stasis dermatitis does not benefit from antimicrobial
therapy. It is important to distinguish between the two. The provider
should be mindful of the fact that bacterial cellulitis can occur on skin
with underlying stasis dermatitis. (See link below for bacterial cellulitis)
Common risk factors for venous stasis include advancing age, family
history of venous disease, increased body mass index, smoking, a history of
trauma, prior venous thrombosis and pregnancy. Chronic venous disease and
arterial vascular disease have some common risk factors (eg, smoking,
obesity) and pathophysiological processes. The most common symptoms reported
by patients with chronic venous disease are limb discomfort (tired, heavy
legs), pain, and limb swelling. Swelling is often worse with prolonged
standing and improves with leg elevation and walking. The skin of the
anterior surfaces of the lower legs often has brown or blue-grey
People with venous stasis are prone to develop stasis dermatitis which
is one of the most common and earliest dermatologic signs of chronic venous
insufficiency. Stasis dermatitis is an inflammatory process that presents as
an eczematous rash characterized by itching, erythema, scaling, weeping,
erosions, and crusting. Longstanding cases may develop lipodermatosclerosis
a fibrosing panniculitis of the subcutaneous tissue. Lipodermatosclerosis
typically starts with a firm area of induration at the medial ankle. As the
process progresses, the entire leg lower leg can become involved with
extension up to the mid leg in more advanced cases. The skin overlying the
panniculitis is typically heavily pigmented and bound down to the
subcutaneous tissues. Brawny edema above the fibrotic area and on the foot
below is seen in advanced cases. Leukocytosis and fever are common in people
Chronic venous disease is the most common cause of leg ulcers. They
are usually found low on the medial ankle over a perforating vein, or along
the course of the great or small saphenous veins. They occur more proximally
if precipitated by trauma. Venous ulcers are not found on the forefoot or
above the level of the knee. Venous ulcers can be multiple or single, and
can be exquisitely tender, shallow, exudative and have a granulation base.
The ulcer borders are usually irregular but not undermined. They can extend
circumferentially around the leg if left untreated.
Arterial ulcers are typically painful, and punched out or stellate. The
surrounding skin is red and taut. Some arterial ulcers are pale - others have
a black or yellow eschar. They are often associated with trauma and commonly
occur on the foot over pressure points. There may be other signs of arterial
insufficiency on the lower limb including thin atrophic or hairless skin,
poor pedal pulses, diminished capillary refill, or hypertrophic deformed
Patients with stasis or lipodermatosclerosis are prone to bouts of
bacterial cellulitis, usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus or encapsulated
streptococci. Typically, stasis dermatitis develops slowly, over a week or
more. It is often bilateral. The onset of bacterial cellulitis is usually
abrupt, typically developing over 1 or 2 days. Bacterial cellulitis often
starts in one area and spreads to adjacent areas. Bacterial cellulitis is
unilateral. Both can present with fever and leukocytosis.
In a patient with stasis and cellulitis and the physician is uncertain
about whether bacterial cellulitis is present, the physician should consider
a trial of bed rest, leg elevation, and if there is fluid overload, diuresis
If the cellulitis improves in 24-48 hours, antibacterial therapy and the
attendant adverse reactions can be avoided. If it is clear that bacterial
cellulitis has occurred, antimicrobial therapy should be given.
Stevens et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2014, 59(2): e10-52

Peripheral vein suppurative thrombophlebitis may require surgical intervention
in addition to antimicrobial therapy. The usual treatment for jugular vein
suppurative thrombophlebitis (Lemierre's syndrome) and vena cava suppurative
thrombophlebitis is prolonged antimicrobial therapy, with or without
radiological or thrombolytic clot removal. Consult Infectious Diseases and
Modify antimicrobial regimen and narrow coverage based on results of culture and
A minimum of 4 to 6 weeks of antimicrobial therapy is appropriate and may be
abbreviated in peripheral vein infections based on patient specific factors.
Antimicrobial therapy should be continued until there is definite clinical
response and oral antimicrobial therapy may be used after completion of initial
Empirical treatment for peripheral vein infections and central vein infections
Empirical treatment for jugular vein infection (also known as Lemierre's) or
Consultation with Surgery and Infectious Diseases is encouraged.

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease caused by the spirochete Treponema
pallidum that can manifest as a variety of signs or symptoms. Primary syphilis
typically consists of painless ulcers or chancre at the site of infection with
regional adenopathy. Secondary syphilis often includes a skin rash (disseminated
and/or including the palms and soles), fever, malaise, mucocutaneous lesions and
lymphadenopathy. Tertiary syphilis includes those with cardiovascular or
Latent syphilis is a period of disease when a patient does not have symptoms but
is found to be infected through serologic testing. Early latent syphilis refers
to latent syphilis acquired within the preceding year and late latent syphilis
refers to all other cases of latent syphilis. Neurosyphilis, Ocular syphilis or
Otosyphilis, can occur at any stage of syphilis with early manifestations (e.g.
meningitis, stroke, vision or hearing loss) occurring within the first months to
years of infection and late manifestations (e.g. dementia, tabes dorsalis)
A presumptive diagnosis is made through use of a nontreponemal or serologic test
(i.e. rapid plasma reagin [RPR]) and a treponemal test (i.e. fluorescent
treponemal antibody absorbed [FTA-ABS]). Direct methods through darkfield
microscopy and direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) must be used for definitive
diagnosis since T. pallidum cannot be cultured.
Persons with sexual contact with a person with primary, secondary or early
latent syphilis within the last 90 days should be presumptively treated even if

Uncomplicated cystitis is defined as symptomatic bladder inflammation caused by
bacterial infections in people with structurally and neurogenically normal
urinary tract. Symptoms usually include dysuria, lower abdominal pain, and
urgency. Most cases of uncomplicated cystitis occur in pre-menopausal,
non-pregnant, sexually active young women and is commonly associated with
Enterobacteriaceae (e.g. E. coli and Klebsiella sp.) and occasionally S.
Cystitis is considered complicated when it occurs in pregnant women, people
with abnormalities of the urinary tract, immunocompromised individuals and those
who have persistent, recurrent, or relapsed infections, or treatment failure are
considered complicated. Diagnosis and treatment of complicated cystitis is
The presence of pyuria (>7 wbc/hpf) or positive leukocyte esterase, urine
nitrate, or urine bacteria is not a sufficient indication for antibiotic
treatment. Asymptomatic bacteriuria occurs in patients who have bacteria in the
urine with no symptoms of cystitis, and with few exceptions, should not be
treated. Diagnosis and treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria is further
The prevalence of antimicrobial resistance among bacteria associated with
uncomplicated cystitis has increased. A urine culture should be considered in a
patient who has had substantial involvement with healthcare or exposure to
antimicrobials. If a patient fails to respond to therapy, a urine culture should
For women with recurrent uncomplicated cystitis (2 episodes in 6 months or 3 or
more episodes in 12 months), suppressive therapy is indicated after infection is
eradicated and non-antimicrobial prevention methods, such as increased fluid
intake and avoiding spermicide, are considered. Consider consulting Women's

Contents.Text: Upper respiratory infections include several common syndromes including
the common cold, bronchitis (see below), pharyngitis (see below) and sinusitis
(see below). Most are caused by viruses and there is no benefit from
antimicrobial therapy. If a patient presents with a URI, consider specific
infections that do respond to antimicrobial therapy like herpes simplex
stomatitis, pertussis or thrush. If no condition that benefits from

Treatment for chlamydial or non-gonococcal urethritis
URETHRITIS ASSOCIATED WITH SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES
The main differential in a person who presents with dysuria is between cystitis
and urethritis. Bacterial urethritis is more likely in people with mild
dysuria, onset over a few days, or recent sexual contact.
The two most common sexually transmitted urethritis pathogens are Neisseria
gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Nucleic acid amplification tests for
these pathogens are more sensitive than culture and should be used for patients
at risk for sexually transmitted urethritis.
For patients who have recently been treated for urethritis
When dysuria is from a sexually transmitted disease, the patient's sexual
partner(s) during the previous 60 days should be evaluated for sexually
If diagnostic tests for the cause of urethritis are not feasible, therapy for
both N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis should be given to partners.
Initial treatment of patients and sex partners
Patients and partners are often infected with both N. gonorrhoeae and C.
trachomatis. Treat for both pathogens unless one is ruled out by lab test.

Bladder catheters are used for urinary drainage, or as a means to collect

placement of catheters, BUT too frequently they are used without proper
indication or continued longer than needed.Unwarranted urinary catheters
Daily evaluation of the ongoing need for the catheter is essential to reduce
complications including catheter-assosciated urinary tract infection.
Alternatives to indwelling urethral catheterization should be considered
and include intermittent catheterization, external sheath (ie,condom)

Contents.Text: Management of patients with neurogenic bladder/spinal cord injury
The goal of an SCI bladder program is to preserve renal function while
eliminating urine at regular and socially acceptable times, avoiding high
bladder pressures, retention, incontinence, and infection.
Clean intermittent catheterization, which is the removal of the catheter
immediately after bladder decompression with recatheterization on a scheduled
Clean technique intermittent catheterization has a lower infection rate
compared with with the use of indwelling catheters.
basis ispreferred. Clean intermittent catheterization is performed at regular
intervals, usually every 4 hours. A bladder volume of less than 500 mls
of urine is targeted in order to avoid bladder distention, pressure, and reflux
as well as to reduce the incidence of infections.
Intermittent urinary incontinence is expected. Condom catheters (for men)
and adult diapers are important short-term interventions. Recommend rule
out infection and adjust the frequency of intermittent catheterization

The indwelling catheter should be changed each month to minimize infections.

Contents.Item: PSJZID CLINDAMYCIN 2% CRM VAG 1APPLFUL CREAM QHS
Contents.Text: Clindamycin phosphate vaginal cream 2%, contents of 1 applicator
Vaginitis usually presents with discharge, itching, irritation, odor, or pain.
Bacterial vaginosis is the most common form of vaginitis. Normal hydrogen
peroxide and lactic acid producing vaginal flora, including Lactobacillus
species, is reduced and high concentrations of anaerobic bacterial pathogens are
present. Pathogenic bacteria commonly include Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma
hominis, Nobiluncus, Prevotella and other Gram-negative anaerobes.
Vaginal pH should be measured, and the specimen should be examined under the
microscope for identification of clue cells (epithelial cell coated with
bacteria). In bacterial vaginosis the vaginal pH is high (> 4.5), the discharge
is homogenous and gray-white, and the specimen has a positive amine or whiff
test characterized by a fishy odor before or after addition of 10% KOH.
Bacterial vaginosis nucleic acid amplification tests are available for common
pathogens to aide in identification of pathogen(s).
Bacterial vaginosis may be transmitted sexually. Patients at risk of sexually
transmitted infections should be assessed for treatment.

Workowski et al., MMWR Recomm Rep, 2021, 70(4)1-187

Chemotherapy with purine analogues such as fludarabine, cladribine, or
pentostatin results in major cellular-immunodeficiency that may outlast the
exposure by months and enhances the risk for viral infections.
Recommend antiviral prophylaxis for patients treated with purine analogues,
if at least one of the following risk factors is present:
e) Prolonged Mild or Moderate Neutropenia: Mild<1000 Neutrophils /
L (Grade III neutropenia) OR Moderate: <500 Neutrophils/L
Duration: Antiviral prophylaxis should be initiated in the first week of
therapy and continued until 2 months after completion of therapy.
Alemtuzumab is a potent reactivator of latent intracellular pathogens,
including CMV. Chemotherapy with alemtuzumab results in major cellular-
immunodeficiency that may outlast the exposure by months and enhances the
risk for viral infections. The risk of viral disease increases with the
intensity and duration of functional T-cell suppression experienced with
Duration: Initiate antiviral prophylaxis with alemtuzumab therapy and
continue therapy for at least 2 months after last dose or until CD4 counts
are greater than or equal to 200 cells/ul, whichever is later.

Contents.Text: PREVENTION OF ANTIVIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Prophylaxis for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) or Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)
Prophylaxis for Influenza and Other Respiratory Viruses
Yearly influenza vaccination with inactivated vaccine is recommended for all
patients receiving chemotherapy for malignancy and all family and household
Optimal timing of vaccination for patients being treated for cancer is not
established, but serologic responses may be best between chemotherapy cycles
(greater than 7 days after the last treatment) or greater than 2 weeks
Patients with active malignant disease are at higher risk for upper
respiratory infections due to influenza, parainfluenza or respiratory
syncytial virus (RSV). Although response to vaccination with the attenuated
influenza vaccine in patients on chemotherapy is variable, ranging
from 24-75%, immnunoprophylaxis with the influenza vaccine is recommended for
patients with active malignant disease or chemotherapy, lymphoproliferative
disease, or multiple myeloma. In areas and seasons where influenza is
endemic, chemoprophylaxis can be considered in addition to vaccination in
exposed patients with a high risk of influenza complications.
Prophylaxis and monitoring for CMV reactivation is not recommended unless the
patient has received an allogeneic HSCT. Usually the recommendations for
surveillance and prophylaxis of CMV infections from the institution
performing the HSCT will be followed.
Reactivation of chronic hepatitis B in patients undergoing immunosuppressive
or antineoplastic treatment is a severe complication. Patients with positive
HBsAg, chronic hepatitis B infection, or a previous episode of HBV
reactivation who will receive immunosuppressive therapy should receive
Recommend routine testing for Hepatitis B prior to initiating Rituximab

PREVENTION OF VIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Viral infections reactivate in a small percentage of people with malignancy.
Most viral infections in patients with hematologic malignancies or solid
tumors result from reactivation of asymptomatic latent infections,
predominantly of herpes viruses, including herpes simplex virus (HSV),
varicella zoster virus (VZV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV). Exogenous
respiratory tract infections caused by influenza, parainfluenza
or respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) are less common.
The main risk factor for clinically relevant reactivation is profound
disruption of cellular immune response, usually due to chemotherapy.
The duration and severity of neutropenia are of lesser importance.
The risk of viral disease increases with the intensity and duration
of functional T-cell suppression. Patients receiving conventionally
dosed chemotherapy regimens for solid tumors experience no major
T-cell suppression and do not have a higher incidence of

Contents.Text: PREVENTION OF ANTIVIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Solid tumors do not significantly compromise the cellular immune system.
Therefore, patients are at low risk for opportunistic viral infections.
Documented invasive viral infections are very rare. Coincidental
mucocutaneous infections by herpes simplex are easily treated and do not
result in life-threatening invasive infections. Reactivation of
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) or Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is rarely observed.
In patients with acute leukemia, treatment is highly aggressive and consists
of a combination of various cytotoxic agents administered in sequential
cycles as induction, consolidation and maintenance therapy. Persistent, i.e.
>10 days and profound neutropenia (<500 neutrophils) regularly occurs and
correlates with the risk of developing fever and infections. Almost all viral
infections during neutropenia constitute reactivations of herpes viruses.
None of the available studies demonstrated an effect of antiviral prophylaxis
on the initiation of antibiotic treatment, number of febrile days, duration
of antibiotic treatment, and onset of opportunistic infections. Therefore, no
recommendation for antiviral prophylaxis in patients with acute leukemia can
Patients undergoing leukemia induction therapy should receive prophylaxis.
Rituximab is a monoclonal anti-CD-20 antibody used for treatment of
lymphomas. It leads to a profound depletion of circulating B-cells. B-cells
recover usually within 3-6 months after treatment. Prolonged administration
of rituximab (e.g., maintenance treatment >12 months) may result in a
significant decrease of levels of immunoglobulin M. Parvovirus B19 and JC-
papovavirus infections have been reported with maintenance rituximab therapy,
but drugs that would prevent these infections are not available. There is no
substantial increase in risk of reactivation of herpes viruses (including
Recommend routine testing for Hepatitis B virus prior to initiating Rituximab

Contents.Text: APPROACH TO FOOT ULCER WITH INFECTION
Whenever possible, material should be obtained for Gram stain and culture.
Specimens from deep ulcer biopsy, aspiration, or bone biopsy are superior to
wound swab or drainage.Pathogen identification is especially important because
therapy is often given for weeks.
While foot ulcers in patients with diabetes typically have many bacterial
species on the surface, disease is usually caused by only one or two.When
Staphylococcus aureus is present in a surface culture, it is usually a pathogen
in the deeper tissues.Therapy can usually be directed against the predominant
or virulent organisms found on surface cultures and need not be active against
every isolate.To reduce uncertainty it is better to obtain deeper cultures.
Bacteria that are most likely to be responsible for invasive infection include
S. aureus, streptococci, enteric gram-negative bacilli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa,
and anaerobes typical of the human enteric flora.When there is no evidence
that would direct therapy to any single organism, empirical therapy should be
