Contents.Text: Empirical antimicrobials should be given only in cases of severe acute disease
or high-risk conditions: fever, >/= 6 stools in 24 hours, volume depletion
requiring hospitalization, severe abdominal pain, immune compromise, cardiac
If in the preceding two months the patient has taken a PPI or has been
hospitalized for three or more days, consider Clostridium difficile infection.
Bloody diarrhea can represent hemorrhagic colitis or dysentery. Antimicrobial
therapy and antimotility agents are not recommended in most patients with bloody
diarrhea due to an increased risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome when using these
agents. Obtain a stool sample for enteric pathogen PCR testing and reserve
antimicrobial and antimotility agent treatment until results are known. Enteric
pathogen PCR testing results are reported within 2 hours between 7am and 11pm.
For more information on when an antimicrobial is indicated or if the patient has
severe/life threatening diarrhea or is immunocompromised, contact Infectious
Empiric antimicrobial treatment for non-bloody severe acute diarrhea
Subacute or chronic (>/= 14 days of symptoms)
Primary treatment is hydration and electrolyte replacement. Empiric
antimicrobial therapy is not indicated. Investigate for the cause of diarrhea.
Gastroenterology and/or Infectious Diseases involvement is encouraged.
Mandell chapter: Nausea, Vomiting, and Noninflammatory Diarrhea

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU CAP TREATED IN OUTPT SETTING
Contents.DisplayText: CAP treated in an outpatient setting (Outpatient)
Contents.Text: CAP treated in an outpatient setting
Empirical regimens listed here cover the usual pathogens associated with CAP,
including atypical pathogens.Specific therapy should be guided by culture
CAP Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI) or PORT Score
The CAP pneumonia severity index is useful for estimation of mortality risk for
a patient with pneumonia.Pre-estimated risk can then be used to determine how
aggressively to treat the patient's pneumonia and whether the patient can be
treated safely outside of the hospital.
The Community-Acquired Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI) is a guide and
should be used to augment clinical judgment. If social circumstances
or cognitive dysfunction would interfere with success of outpatient
treatment, the patient should be hospitalized.
If a patient has taken an antimicrobial in the previous 3 months, it is prudent
to avoid giving the same or a similar drug for the current episode of pneumonia.
(SEE INPATIENT CDSS for CAP treated in an Inpatient Setting)
Fine MJ, et al. N Engl J Med. (1997) 336: 243-250

Contents.Text: Infectious diarrhea caused by viral pathogens such as Adenovirus, Astrovirus,
Norovirus, Rotavirus, and Sapovirus is usually self-limited. Treatment includes
supportive measures such as oral rehydration and unrestricted nutrition.
Antiviral therapy is not recommended and for most viruses is unavailable.
Antimotility agents may be used for one or two days in patients with mild to
moderate volume depletion. Antiemetic agents may be used for one or two days in
Mandell chapter: Nausea, Vomiting, and Noninflammatory Diarrhea

Contents.Text: Complicated cystitis is defined as symptomatic bladder inflammation and symptoms
due to a bacterial infection in people with certain conditions (see below).
Symptoms usually include dysuria, lower abdominal pain, and urgency. Complicated
cystitis is commonly associated with Enterobacteriaceae, but more resistant
pathogens occur, including the Gram-positive pathogens staphylococci and
Signs and symptoms that may indicate infection has extended beyond the bladder
include fever/other signs of systemic infection, flank pain, costovertebral
tenderness, and pelvic or perianal pain in men. Pyelonephritis should be
Urine culture should be obtained before antimicrobials are given to guide
Prostatitis should be considered in men with recurrence of urinary tract
When patients who require paraenteral therapy are afebrile, clinically stable,
and can take oral medication, convert to oral therapy based on the
identification and susceptibility of the isolate.
Cystitis is considered complicated when one or more of the following is present:
o Structural or neurogenic abnormalities (e.g. presence of obstruction, catheter
or nephrostomy tubes, neurogenic bladder, renal failure or transplantation)
o Persistent infection, relapse, recurrence, or treatment failure
o In some cases, men and patients admitted to health care settings may be
Treat for 7 days. If patient is febrile, may extend duration up to 14 days total
*Avoid trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole in the first and third trimesters
Severe disease or if patient cannot take oral therapy
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS
Enterobacteria including E. coli, klebsiella, and proteus
*Avoid trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole in the first and third trimesters
S. aureus is an uncommon urinary tract pathogen and presence in the urine may be
due to hematogenous seeding from another site. Blood cultures are indicated to
rule out bacteremia in patients who have S. aureus isolated from the urine.
Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.

Contents.Text: Conjunctivitis is associated with viral or bacterial pathogens. Viral
conjunctivitis presents with watery discharge. Bacterial infections are more
likely to present with thick exudate and conjunctival injection. Allergic
conjunctivitis typically presents with stringy mucus. If there is pus
(hypopion), corneal involvement, possible bacterial conjunctivitis, or
Viral conjunctivitis is most commonly caused by adenovirus. It is self-limited
and antivirals provide no benefit. Symptomatic treatment with ophthalmic
antihistamine/decongestants and warm or cool compresses may relieve symptoms.
Bacterial conjunctivitis is most commonly associated with Staphylococcus aureus,
Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus spp., Moraxella catarrhalis,
Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria spp. or enteric gram-negative rods. It is
generally self-limited, but topical antimicrobials reduce duration of symptoms
and limit person-to-person spread of infection. If symptoms do not improve after
2 days of antimicrobial therapy, the patient should be seen by an
Treatment for severe cases of bacterial conjunctivitis involving suppuration or
Consult ophthalmology and begin topical antimicrobials.
days then 2 drops QID for 5 days ($) [M]

Keep affected areas dry and clean.

Contents.Text: Link to Shigella/Enteroinvasive E. coli menu
Enteroaggretive E. coli (EAEC), Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC), and
EAEC infection can cause watery diarrhea with mucus that is occasionally bloody.
It is more common in patients with HIV and those who have traveled to developing
regions. EPEC infection is associated with severe acute watery diarrhea that is
occasionally bloody. ETEC infection causes acute watery diarrhea that is
occasionally severe. It is most common in travelers to tropical regions who are
exposed to contaminated food and water.
Antibiotic therapy is not required for mild to moderate disease caused by these
organisms because diarrhea often resolves on its own. Do not use antimotility
agents in patients with bloody stool.
Antimicrobial treatment in patients with AIDS
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) and Shiga Toxin-producing E. coli (STEC)
EHEC and STEC disease often presents as bloody diarrhea. It is more common in
people who have consumed undercooked meats or poultry, fruits or unpasteurized
fruit juices, vegetables, leafy greens or seed sprouts. Exposure risks include
swimming in or drinking untreated fresh water and visiting a farm, petting zoo,
healthcare facility, prison or childcare facility.
Treatment includes supportive measures such as volume repletion and
administering appropriate nutrition. Do not use antimotility or antimicrobial
agents as they can increase shiga-toxin release and increase the risk of
EIEC disease typically presents as watery diarrhea, sometimes progressing to
bloody diarrhea. Refer to Shigella/Enteroinvasive E. coli menu for
Brunette, Gary W. CDC Yellow Book 2018: Oxford University Press, 2017
Sanford keyword: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli / Shiga toxin-producing E. coli
Shane et al, Clinical Infectious Diseases 2017, 65(12):45-80

Contents.Text: DIARRHEA WITH GIARDIA DUODENALIS (ALSO KNOWN AS G. LAMBLIA AND G.INTESTINALIS)
Illness with Giardia is typically subacute but varies widely in its time course.
Treatment is necessary when the patient has symptomatic disease. Diarrhea,
abdominal pain, bloating, belching, flatus, nausea, and vomiting are present
acutely and after several days give way to flatus, loose stools, belching, and
Asymptomatic carriage of Giardia is common in household contacts of people who
are infected with Giardia. Treatment of asymptomatic patients can be considered
if they have contact with immunocompromised or pregnant people or live or work
in settings where there is risk of spreading infection to others (e.g., food
Sanford keyword: Giardia duodenalis (G. intestinalis, G. lamblia)

Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for parenteral therapy

Epididymitis is inflammation of the epididymis and when testicles are involved
is referred to as epididymo-orchitis. Acute epididymitis is the most common
cause of scrotal pain in adults. Other features include scrotal erythema and
edema, pyuria, dysuria, thickened epididymis, swollen testis, and is usually
unilateral. It is primarily caused by infection but can also result from trauma
and autoimmune diseases. Testicular torsion should be ruled out before
treatment. Most cases in men aged 35 and older, those with recent urinary tract
instrumentation or surgery (e.g., prostate biopsy, vasectomy) are associated
with enteric Gram-negative rods. Most cases in men under age 35 are associated
with N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis. Resistant organisms are more likely if
the patient has been in the hospital for more than 48 hours or received a course
of antibiotics. There is increasing resistance in urinary pathogens to
A urine analysis, urine culture and urine nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)
should be performed in all cases of suspected epididymitis before starting
Patients at risk of sexually transmitted infections should be assessed for
treatment. Refer to the Urogenital section of the Antimicrobial CDSS for more
Patients with bacterial epididymitis treated with antibiotics should improve
within two or three days. If no improvement is noted, other causes of scrotal
pain and referral to a urologist should be considered.
Management should include bed rest, analgesics, and scrotal elevation. Older men
should have their residual urinary volume checked. If the residual volume is
elevated, the patient should be seen by a urologist as epididymitis is unlikely
to respond if the prostate is blocking the vas deferens.

Empirical treatment in men who do not practice insertive anal intercourse

Contents.Text: Fever of unknown origin (FUO) is the occurrence of several episodes of fever
greater than 101 degrees Fahrenheit over a time period of at least 3 weeks
despite 1 week of hospital evaluation. Cases with FUO are often classified in
four categories: (1) classical, (2) neutropenic, (3) nosocomial, and (4) fever
in persons with HIV/AIDS. Empirical antimicrobial therapy is rarely indicated
Note that FUO in neutropenic patients refers to persistent fever that has
remained undiagnosed after extensive diagnostic work and empirical antimicrobial
therapy. New fever in patients with profound neutropenia is a different
syndrome and does require empirical antimicrobial therapy. Infectious Diseases
should be involved in any case where empirical treatment for fever of unknown
Mandell Chapter: Fever of Unknown Origin

Contents.Text: Foot ulcers WITH infection of surrounding tissues
FOOT ULCER IN PATIENT WITH DIABETES MELLITUS
Foot ulcers in patients with diabetes mellitus are colonized with bacteria.
Antimicrobials should not be used to treat colonization.
Cases with infection of surrounding tissues signified by erythema, warmth, local
tenderness, or purulent discharge should be treated with antimicrobials. Pain
may not be present in patients with neuropathy.In patients with substantial
vascular disease, erythema and warmth may not be present and instead the tissues
will be dusky, mottled, or cool.Capillary refill may be impaired.Patients
with diabetes and ulcers are at risk for gangrenous infections.If there is any
suggestion of gangrene, consult surgery immediately.

UpToDate: Treatment and prevention of invasive aspergillosis

disease, but other manifestations include central nervous system infection,
rhinosinusitis, endocarditis, gastrointestinal disease, annd others.

Contents.Text: Avoid using fluconazole empirically to treat candidal infections in patients who
have received an imidazole in the previous year.
Treatment of thrush or oropharyngeal candidiasis
Oropharyngeal candidal disease may present in different patterns, like white
plaques in the oropharyngeal area, erythematous macules (often in patients with
Thrush infection often recurs, especially in patients with AIDS. Consult MRTC
clinic or Infectious Diseases (MRTC may also be consulted in the MVAHCS) for
more information on treatment of recurrent infection.
Alternative for patient who cannot swallow tablets
Fluconazole is preferred empirical therapy in most cases. Amphotericin B should
be used empirically in patients who have received an azole antifungal drug
recently, or in patients who are critically ill.
Duration of therapy is dependent upon location, severity of infection,
and response to therapy. Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.

Contents.Text: Localized purulent infections include furuncles, carbuncles and cutaneous
abscesses. Nearly all are caused by Staphylococcus aureus. A furuncle is a
inflamed nodule that usually develops as a complication of folliculitis. A
carbuncle is a more extensive lesion that extends further into the subcutaneous
tissue.Contact a wound care nurse for more information.
Incision and drainage is the mainstay of therapy for carbuncles, cutaneous
The decision to administer antibiotics directed against S. aureus as an adjunct

inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) or in patients with markedly impaired

Treat for 5 days and extend/modify treatment if not improved in this time.

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ABX LIVER AMEBIC ABSCESS
Contents.Text: Link to Amebic Liver Abscess menu
Liver abscess should be suspected in all patients with fever, leukocytosis, and
a space-occupying liver lesion. Liver abscesses fall broadly into two
categories: pyogenic and amebic. In the United States, pyogenic liver abscess is
much more common. Amebic liver abscess occurs almost exclusively in travelers
and immigrants. If amebic liver abscess is suspected, select the link below.
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS
Mandell chapter: Infections of the Liver and Biliary System
Solomkin et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2010, 50:133-64

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION OUTPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Opt)

Contents.Text: The important human pathogens are Enterococcus faecium and Enterococcus
faecalis. The antimicrobial susceptibilities that are reported for enterococci
depend on the site of the sample. For all enterococci the microbiology
laboratory reports susceptibility for ampicillin and vancomycin. Additionally
the lab reports fluoroquinolone susceptibility for urinary isolates and
susceptibility to gentamicin synergy for bloodstream isolates. For more
information on culture and susceptibilities, contact the microbiology laboratory
Ampicillin is the drug of choice for enterococcal infections. Piperacillin is
also active against enterococcus. Cephalosporins are ineffective as single
agents for enterococcal infections. For patients who are allergic to penicillin
or infected with penicillin-resistant enterococcus, vancomycin is the preferred
drug. Nitrofurantoin is effective in urinary tract infections only. Linezolid
must be reserved for cases where no other drug can be used as it has many side
effects and drug interactions, is expensive, is bacteriostatic rather than
bactericidal, and its use promotes resistance.
Combination regimens include a primary anti-enterococcal agent (ampicillin or
vancomycin) plus gentamicin or streptomycin are synergistic in vitro and are
needed for severe infections like endocarditis or prosthetic joint infections.
See relevant disease/syndrome sections for more information. Milder diseases
like cystitis or wound infection can usually be treated with a single drug. For
more information on treatment of enterococcal infections, contact Infectious
Mandell chapter: Enterococcus Species, Streptococcus gallolyticus Group, and

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU GRAM-POS TREAT S. AUREUS
ORZID3 GMENU GRAM-POS COAG NEG STAPH

Contents.Text: Staphylococcus aureus is a virulent pathogen, and staphylococcal disease tends
to relapse. Optimal therapy often involves intravenous therapy for defined
durations. See sections on specific syndromes (e.g., bacteremia or
Coagulase-negative staphylococci, including Staphylococcus epidermidis and
several less common species, are less virulent than S. aureus and are most
commonly pathogenic when they colonize plastic or metal devices in a patient
(e.g., intravenous catheters, prosthetic joints or heart valves). S.
lugdunensis is an uncommon but virulent coagulase-negative staphylococcus
species. S. saprophyticus is associated with urinary tract infections in women.
Beta-lactam antimicrobials are the most active drugs against beta-lactam
susceptible staphylococci. Penicillin is superior for penicillin-susceptible
staphylococci, but most strains are resistant. Nafcillin and oxacillin are
nearly as active as penicillin. Cefazolin or ceftriaxone (also beta-lactams are
next best. Vancomycin, a glycopeptide, is less active than the beta-lactams.
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, minocycline, and clindamycin are less effective
than beta-lactams for treatment of methicillin-susceptible staphylococcal
infections, but may be useful in patients with severe penicillin allergy. For
minocycline, and clindamycin are useful alternatives to to vancomycin, as they
are inexpensive and available in both intravenous and oral formulations. They
are preferred over linezolid in most circumstances because linezolid is
expensive, toxic with long-term use, and needed for treatment of highly
Combination regimens include a primary anti-staphylococcal agent (beta-lactam or
vancomycin) plus one or more supplemental drugs (e.g. gentamicin and/or
rifampin) often synergistic against staphylococci in vitro, but there is no
evidence that combination therapy improves outcomes in staphylococcal infections
in humans. Combination therapy has become the community standard for treatment
of prosthetic-valve staphylococcal endocarditis based on experimental models and
limited clinical data that combination therapy is superior (see endocarditis
Mandell chapter: Endocarditis and Intravascular Infections

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION OUTPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Opt)

Contents.Text: Viridans streptococci are a heterogeneous group defined by their production of
green pigment on blood agar. Clinically important members of this group include
S. mutans, S. mitis, and S. sanguis. S. anginosus (formerly S. milleri) and
Streptococcus bovis are described separately. Viridans streptococci are
important, common pathogens in endocarditis and can also be contaminants in
cultures of blood and other specimens. Consult Infectious Diseases for more
Refer to the Cardiovascular Section of the Inpatient Antimicrobialc CDSS for
Optimal therapy depends on both the disease or syndrome and the pathogen. See
Preferred treatment is penicillin or cefazolin. Vancomycin should be used only
in patients with beta-lactam allergy, or if beta-lactam resistance is strongly
suspected. For serious disease, consider addition of gentamicin for synergy.
Contact Infectious Diseases for more information.
Intravenous antimicrobials are indicated. Refer to Inpatient Animicrobial CDSS.
Mandell Chapter: Viridans Streptococci, Nutritionally Variant Streptococci,
Groups C and G Streptococci, and Other Related Organisms

Contents.Text: H. pylori infection is associated with peptic ulcers, gastritis, gastric

Contents.Text: Permethrin 1% lotion Apply to affected area for 10 minutes then comb out
Lice are parasitic insects. Human lice survive by feeding on human blood.
To make a diagnosis, use a nit comb, bright light, or lens to find a louse
living on the scalp.Dead nits may remain for months after successful
treatment.Dead nits are usually located more than 6 mm from the scalp.
Lice are often transmitted by infected clothing and bedclothes but not by
ordinary furniture that is not typically in contact with hair or scalp.Refer
to the following for advice on household cleaning for lice infestations:
Repeat if live lice are seen 7-10 days after treatment.

Hepatitis B evaluation for patients receiving Anti-CD20 Antibody Treatment
Before initiating anti-CD20 antibody treatment (rituximab, obinutuzumab,
ofatumumab) test all patients for Hepatitis B. Testing should be completed
within the last 6 months prior to the start of the initial infusion (same day
is acceptable, but not preferred). Annual Hepatitis B screening is not
necessary unless there are risk factors.
More information at VHA Oncology SharePoint site for hepatitis B reactivation:
Order Hepatitis B Serology Panel for all patients:
Includes hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), anti-hepatitis B core antibody
IF HBsAg or anti-HBcAb is positive, Consult GI for all services except
IF HBsAg or anti-HBcAB is positive for an ONCOLOGY patient initial orders:
a) Assess HIV status. To avoid potential HIV resistance-
refer HIV positive patients to ID for management.
b) Obtain Labs: Comprehensive Metabolic AND Phosphorus
c) Obtain HBV DNA level (viral load) initially
d) Schedule GI Clinic Consult for co-management to order
liver imaging and follow-up as indicated.
e) Start hepatitis B antiviral treatment (see below)
Continue antivirals throughout anti-CD20 Ab therapy and for an additional
12 months to prevent hepatitis B reactivation, hepatitis, liver failure,
Obtain HBV DNA level (viral load) every 3 months
IF PATIENT IS CURRENTLY ON HEPATITIS B ANTIVIRAL THERAPY:

Contents.Text: A chronic inflammatory condition that typically involves occlusion, rupture,
abscess formation and infection of hair follicles as well as secondary infection
of apocrine glands/surrounding tissues. Lesions most often occur in the
intertriginous areas (axillae, inguinal and anogenital) in is associated with
smoking and obesity. There is a 40% genetic predisposition for hidradenitis
suppurativa (HS) and is often accompanied by pain, malodor, and drainage.
Cultures are negative 50% of the time and often are polymicrobial with S.
epidermidis and S. aureus most isolated. The Hurley Staging System is often used
Therapy generally consists of treatment of comorbidities that can exacerbate HS,
avoidance of triggers, pain management, wound care, and topical/oral
antimicrobials. Hormonal agents, steroids, retinoids, and surgery can also be
used to treat certain patients. Biologics may be considered in Stage II-III HS.
Stage I: recurrent nodules and abscesses with minimal scarring
Stage II: limited number of sinuses and/or scarring within a body region
Stage III: multiple or extensive sinuses and/or scarring
Treatment is typically for 12 weeks but may require longer durations in certain
cases. Metronidazole should only be used for a maximum of 6 weeks to avoid
Smoking cessation, weight loss, avoidance of triggers, and pain management
should be part of all treatment plans. Consult Dermatology for use of hormonal
Optional Topical Treatment, May be Used in Addition to Oral Therapies Below:

Contents.Text: Antibody deficiency typically leads to recurrent, severe respiratory tract
infections associated with encapsulated bacteria, especially Streptococcus
pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae, and to a lesser extent, Staphylococcus
aureus. Recurrent otitis media, sinusitis, and pneumonia are common syndromes.
Gastrointestinal disease associated with Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, or
rotavirus is also common in some patients.

Prevention of antiviral infections in a patient with malignancy
Malignancies affect host defenses in many ways.Hematogenous malignancies can
diminish the effectiveness of neutrophils and other cells involved in host
defense.Tumors often disrupt mucous membranes or blood vessels and allow
contaminating organisms into hollow cavities or the bloodstream.Chemotherapy
used to treat these malignancies often impairs mucus membranes and suppresses
Empirical antimicrobials are not indicated for patients with malignancy and
fever unless they have neutropenia or a specific infectious disease, except in
Rich RR, et al, eds.Clinical Immunology

Contents.Text: Several types of neurological dysfunction predispose patients to infectious
diseases.Comatose patients are unable to keep weight off dependent tissues,
predisposing them to decubitus ulcers and pressure necrosis.Atelectasis is
common in obtunded patients who cannot cough or breathe deeply.When patients
require artificial ventilation, intubation compounds the risk of respiratory
Neurological dysfunction of the bladder can interfere with normal bladder
emptying and predisposes patients to bacteriuria.The risk of bacteruria
increases if patients are catheterized.Antimicrobial treatment is not
indicated for asymptomatic bacteriuria.It provides no benefit and increases
risk of colonization with resistant organisms.
Neurological dysfunction of the gastrointestinal or pulmonary systems
predisposes patients to aspiration of oropharyngeal or gastric contents.
Aspiration causes fever, inflammation, and/or pulmonary infiltrate, but does not
require antimicrobial treatment. Bacterial pneumonia occurs in a minority of
patients who experience significant aspiration, typically about 3 days later.
The patient usually improves for the first 2 days and then worsens as bacterial
pneumonia develops with increased fever, new or progressive infiltrates,
Rich RR, et al, eds.Clinical Immunology

Contents.Text: Impetigo is a superficial skin infection that rarely causes systemic
symptoms. Ecthyma is a skin infection characterized by crusted sores
beneath which ulcers form. It is a deep form of impetigo, as the same
bacteria causing the infection are involved. Ecthyma causes deeper
erosions of the skin into the dermis.
Gram stain and culture of the pus or exudates from skin lesions of
impetigo and ecthyma are recommended to help identify whether
Staphylococcus aureus and/or beta-hemolytic Streptococcus is the cause.
Bullous and non-bullous impetigo can be treated with oral or topical
antimicrobials, but oral therapy is recommended for patients with
numerous lesions or in outbreaks affecting several people to help
decrease transmission of infection. Treatment for ecthyma should be an
Treatment for impetigo with few lesions
Treatment for ecthyma and for impetigo with numerous lesions or
whose symptoms have not responded to topical treatment

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU DIARRHEA VIBRIO NON CHOLERA

Contents.Text: Most episodes of acute diarrhea are self limited and do not need to be evaluated
or treated. In most mild to moderate cases, antimicrobial therapy does not
provide benefit and may prolong symptoms or shedding. Antimicrobial therapy is
detrimental in cases involving enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli.
The decision for whether to test stool depends on illness severity and duration,
the likelihood of specific infectious agents and the severity of any underlying
diseases. Send stool sample for enteric pathogen PCR testing if the patient has
volume depletion warranting hospitalization, bloody stool, >/= 6 stools in 24
hours, temperature >38.4?C, or severe abdominal pain or signs of sepsis, or is
>/= 70 years old or substantially immunocompromised. Replace fluid losses and
correct electrolyte imbalances. Patients with diarrhea who were potentially
exposed during a community outbreak of infectious diarrhea should be tested for
the suspected bacterial, viral, and parasitic agents regardless of symptom
Obtain blood cultures if patients have signs of septicemia, suspected enteric
fever (e.g., fever plus recent travel to an endemic area or contact with someone
who has enteric fever), other systemic symptoms, immune compromise, or other
Bloody diarrhea can represent hemorrhagic colitis or dysentery. Antimicrobial
therapy and antimotility agents are not recommended in most patients with bloody
diarrhea due to an increased risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome when using these
agents. Obtain a stool sample for enteric pathogen PCR testing and reserve
antimicrobial and antimotility agent treatment until results are known. Enteric
pathogen PCR testing results are reported within 2 hours between 7am and 11pm.
For more information on when an antimicrobial is indicated or if the patient has
severe/life threatening diarrhea or is immunocompromised, contact Infectious
Treatment of diarrhea caused by specific bacteria, parasites, and viruses
Enteroaggretive E. coli (EAEC), Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC),
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC), Shiga Toxin-producing E. coli (STEC),
Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC), Enteroinvasive E. Coli (EIEC)

Contents.Text: Early treatment as alternative to chemoprophylaxis:
In most cases, if a person is suspected of having been exposed to influenza,
early treatment should signs or symptoms develop is preferred rather than
The provider should explain the early signs and symptoms of influenza to the
patient and advise the patient to immediately contact a health care provider
for evaluation and possible early treatment if these symptoms or signs
develop. Influenza-like symptoms or signs include fever, cough, sore throat,
runny or stuffy nose, body aches, headache, chills, fatigue, vomiting, and
diarrhea. Influenza can present without fever.
Health care providers should use clinical judgment regarding situations where
early recognition of illness and treatment might be an appropriate
Early treatment alternative or chemoprophylaxis may be considered:
*Persons who are part of a high-risk group and are household or close
contacts of someone with influenza-like illness
*Atypical situations (such as case clusters). Contact state health department
Zanamivir is not recommended for patients with chronic respiratory disease such
as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. These patients may have
bronchospasm with zanamivir. If zanamivir must be used, and patients are using
an inhaled bronchodilator, zanamivir should be taken just after the
Zanamivir 2 inhalations (2 x 5 mg) daily for 14 days ($) [O] Duration based on
Chemoprophylaxis duration: 7 days after last known exposure
*For control of outbreaks in institutional settings (long-term care
Chemoprophylaxis duration: minimum of 2 weeks and continuing up to 1 week
after the last known case identified
Note: Antiviral chemoprophylaxis is recommended for all residents, including
those who have received influenza vaccination.

Contents.Text: Pseudomonas, Bordetella, and Brucella spp. usually grow aerobically (but can
show up in an anaerobic bottle). Bacteroides, Fusobacterium, Porphyromonas, and
Prevotella spp. usually grow anaerobically (but can show up in an aerobic
bottle). Most other gram-negative bacilli are facultative, i.e. they can grow
in aerobic or anaerobic culture conditions.
Some antimicrobial combinations are synergistic in vitro against some Gram-
negative bacilli. Combination therapy has not been shown to improve outcomes
in most circumstances. Single drug therapy is used in most cases. Contact
Use susceptibility information to select an antimicrobial when a pathogen is
For intravenous treatment options, please refer to Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS.

There are three typical morphologies (1)large and regular, (2)medium sized and

(anaerobic). Bacillus spp. include Bacillus subtilis (usually a contaminant),
Bacillus cereus, and Bacillus anthracis. Medium-sized Gram-positive bacilli are

Contents.Text: INTERIM REPORT OF GRAM-POSITIVE COCCI IN PAIRS
A preliminary report of gram-positive cocci in pairs suggests staphylococci,
streptococci, or enterococci.If the patient is severely ill, is likely
colonized with resistant organisms, or if staphylococci or enterococci are
likely, treat with vancomycin until susceptibility results are known.
Cephalosporins are not active against enterococci or methicillin-resistant
staphylococcus aureus.If encapsulated streptococci are likely, treat with

Contents.Text: Keratitis is an emergency requiring prompt treatment to prevent vision loss.
Keratitis is associated with viral or bacterial infection, trauma, foreign
bodies, or allergies. About half of cases of infectious keratitis are caused by
bacterial pathogens, most commonly Staphylococcus spp., Streptococcus spp., and
gram-negative bacilli. Viruses are the second leading cause. Fungi and parasites
have also been associated with corneal infection. Obtain corneal scrapings for
gram stain and bacterial and viral cultures and start empirical therapy
If bacterial keratitis is likely, contact ophthalmology to obtain a corneal
scraping and give empirical antibacterial drops immediately. Modify therapy
based on Ophthalmology and/or Infectious Diseases recommendations. Ophthalmic
corticosteroids are contraindicated in patients with keratitis.
Treatment should be continued until ulcer and other signs of infectious
keratitis have resolved. A minimum of two weeks and in rare cases, up to a month
Mild to moderate bacterial keratitis empirical treatment
ophthalmic drops: 1-2 drops q1h ($) [M] in affected eye(s)
Patient may require vancomycin 50mg/mL eye drops q1h in addition to gentamicin
eye drops. Vancomycin eye drops must be specially compounded and managed by

Contents.Text: Pulmonary and/or Infectious Diseases consultations are strongly encouraged for
all cases.Obtain samples for gram stain and culture from fine needle
aspiration whenever possible.Sputum culture is less helpful because it will be
contaminated with upper respiratory flora.Classically, lung abscess is a
complication of mixed anaerobic and aerobic pulmonary infection. The initial
infection may or may not be clinically apparent.Malaise, weight loss, fever,
chills, and malodorous sputum typically develop over a period of weeks.
Cavitation and/or abscess can occur in cases of pneumonia from a single
pathogen, commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Antimicrobial treatment should be directed against the specific pathogen.
Treat for 6 to 8 weeks and adjust treatment based on clinical response.Oral
medications should be used in patients who can take them.

Contents.Text: Cardiac disease associated with Lyme disease (outpatient)
Lyme disease results from the transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi from an
Ixodes spp. tick bite. Patients who display signs of illness or fever within 30
days of removing an attached tick should be evaluated for tick-borne illness.
In the upper Midwest these are Lyme disease, human anaplasmosis, babesiosis, and
Powassan virus disease. Patients who have been bitten by an Ixodes spp. tick
(deer tick) but who do not display signs or symptoms of infection should not
Prophylactic antimicrobial treatment may be beneficial in certain patients who
have been bitten while in endemic areas.
Except for erythema migrans, Lyme disease is a complicated, difficult disease to
diagnose and treat. Infectious Diseases consultation is strongly encouraged.
Mandell Chapter: Lyme Disease (Lyme Borreliosis) Due to Borrelia burgdorferi
Minnesota Department of Health, Disease Control Newsletter (2006), 34.2:9-24

Contents.Text: Patients who have been bitten while in endemic areas of New England, Mid-
Atlantic States, Minnesota and Wisconsin where local rate of Ixodes scapularis
tick infection rate with Borrelia burgdorferi is equal to or greater than 20%
may be treated with prophylactic antibiotics for prevention of Lyme disease.
Using a wait and see method by monitoring for signs and symptoms of Lyme disease
is also an acceptable approach in patients who have been bitten by an Ixodes
All following criteria must be met to be considered for prophylactic treatment:
1. Doxyclycline is not contraindicated (i.e. allergy, pregnant, lactating)
2. Attached tick is reliably identified as an adult or nymphal Ixodes
scalpularis. Follow link below for identification guide:
3. Tick is attached for greater than or equal to 36 hours based on degree of
tick engorgement with blood or likely time of exposure to tick infested area.
4. Prophylaxis must be started within 72 hours after time tick was removed.
5. Patient was exposed to tick bite in endemic areas where rate of Ixodes
scapularis infection with Borrelia burgdorferi is greater than 20%. Minnesota
counties where there is high risk of tickborne disease are shown in the
Providers can call the Minnesota Department of Health (651-201-5414) or the
Wisconsin Department of Health Services (608-266-1865) for specific rates of B.
burdorferi infection of ixodes ticks in area where a patient was exposed.
Contact Infectious Disease if patient was exposed to an Ixodes scapularis tick
bite in New England or Mid-Atlantic States.
Prophylactic treatment if all above criteria are met
Minnesota Department of Health, Disease Control Newsletter (2006), 34.2:9-24
Minnesota Department of Health, Lyme Disease Basics (2017)
Wisconsin Department of Health Services, Tickborne Illness in Wisconsin (2010)
Wisconsin Department of Health Services, Lyme Disease Trends in Wisconsin (2016)

Contents.Text: ERYTHEMA MIGRANS ASSOCIATED WITH LYME DISEASE
Erythema migrans is the first manifestation of Lyme disease in 70-80% of cases.
It is typically an erythematous circular rash, 5cm or larger in diameter, with
induration and central clearing (although other patterns occur). It usually
develops at the site of the bite and/or in one or more distant locations. The
rash occurs 3 to 30 days after the bite. Rashes with onset less than 3 days
after a tick bite are not from Lyme disease.
For pregnant patients or patients with doxycycline allergy

Contents.Text: Acute mastoiditis most commonly occurs as a suppurative complication of acute
otitis media. Diagnosis is supported by CT or MRI imaging and culture of
drainage. Antibiotics and drainage of middle ear are sufficient treatment in
most cases. Mastoidectomy is necessary if abscess has formed in the mastoid
bone. If complication of first episode of acute otitis media, etiologies
typically include Streptococcus pneumonia (most common), Streptococcus pyogenes,
or Staphylococcus aureus. If secondary to chronic otitis media, etiologies
typically include Staphylococcus aureus or Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Patients
usually too ill for outpatient therapy. ENT consultation recommended. Obtain
cultures of auditory canal or middle ear fluid (preferred).
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for parenteral therapy
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for parenteral therapy
Step down treatment after initial intravenous antibiotic treatment in patients
who can tolerate oral therapy. Base selection on culture results. Adjust for a
total duration of 3 weeks of antimicrobial therapy.
Chronic mastoiditis is usually the result of chronic otitis media with
perforation of the tympanic membrane. There is often associated formation of a
cholesteatoma (keratoma). Diagnosis is supported by CT or MRI imaging and
culture of drainage. Long term treatment with topical antimicrobials is first
line therapy. Infection is often polymicrobial, including Staphylococcus aureus,
Pseudomonas aeruginosa and anaerobes. Treatment should be managed in
collaboration with otolaryngology and includes topical antimicrobials, care of
external auditory canal, and is some cases mastoidectomy. If possible, withhold
therapy until a pathogen is identified by culture of drainage to direct therapy.
Specific drug choice dictated by culture results.
Mandell chapter: Otitis Externa, Otitis Media, and Mastoiditis
Loh et. al., The Journal of Laryngology & Otology. 2018, 132(2)96-104.

In addition to antimicrobial therapy, several non-pharmacological treatments
improve the outcome of cellulitis. Elevation and immobilization of the
affected limb reduces swelling.Heat reduces discomfort.
Prevent tinea pedis infection by keeping feet clean and dry.In patients with
peripheral edema, good skin hygiene and support stockings reduce the incidence
In many cases of cellulitis, the affected area is usually not well-
differentiated from unaffected areas of the skin. Erysipelas is a special case
with typically a well-defined border and raised, orange-peel appearance.

MORE ABOUT PHARYNGITIS/ TONSILLITIS AND THE MODIFIED CENTOR SCORE
As most cases are of viral origin, antimicrobials are not indicated in these
cases. Warm saltwater gargle rinses and throat lozenges provide temporary relief
of throat pain. Five to 10% of cases are caused by group A Streptococcus.
Antimicrobial treatment reduces symptoms by one day, prevents suppurative
complications and prevents acute rheumatic fever, an uncommon disease in US
Streptococcal pharyngitis or tonsillitis should be suspected when patients have
fever and exudate on the pharyngeal wall or tonsils without symptoms like cough,
nasal congestion, or runny nose that suggest viral infection or common cold. If
streptococcal pharyngitis is suspected in adults, perform PCR testing for group
A streptococci and treat only if positive.
Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a rare cause of pharyngitis. N. gonorrhoeae should be
considered for patients with risk factors for sexually transmitted diseases. N.
gonorrhoeae infections must be reported to the state health department and this
will be done by Infection Control if the culture is positive.
Used to estimate the likelihood that a patient with sore throat has
streptococcal pharyngitis and whether rapid PCR testing should be performed.
2) Swollen and tender anterior cervical nodes = 1 point
3) Temperature greater than 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Centigrade) = 1
Patients with a score of 0 or 1 are at very low risk. PCR testing and antibiotic
treatment are not indicated. Patients with a score of 2 to 4 are at moderate to
high risk. PCR testing should be obtained in these patients to determine if GAS
is present. In patients with a score of 4 or greater, consider empiric
Stanford et al, Clinical Infectious Diseases. 2012, cis629

The risk of severe, rapidly progressive infections increases when the absolute
neutrophil count (ANC, segmented neutrophils plus bands) is less than 500
cells/microliter.The risk increases dramatically when the ANC is <100
cells/microliter.Because of these risks, patients with fever and neutropenia
to this degree should receive empirical antimicrobial therapy immediately.
Empirical therapy should also be given to patients with fever and ANC 500-1000
cells/microliter when the concentration is expected to be <500 cells/microliter
within the next 48 hours.For this purpose, fever is defined as a single
Since infection can be rapidly progressive and severe, broad-spectrum
antimicrobials are given urgently to patients with neutropenic fever as defined
above.Vancomycin should only be given when there are clear indications for its
Candidates for empirical treatment with oral antimicrobials include those who

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU PROSTHESIS BONE JOINT INFECT
Contents.DisplayText: Infections in bone or joint prostheses (Outpatient)
Contents.Text: Infections in bone or joint prostheses
In acute osteomyelitis, symptoms have been present for several days to weeks.
Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by a longer duration of symptoms,
sometimes months or years, and often dead, necrotic bone is present.There is
considerable overlap between the syndromes of acute and chronic osteomyelitis.
Symptom duration may be unreliable in a patient with neuropathy.
Obtain material for gram stain and culture before initiating antimicrobials.
Blood and bone cultures are ideal.Sinus tracts are often colonized with
multiple species and usually only one or two are pathogens in bone.If
Staphylococcus aureus is present, it is likely to be a pathogen in bone.
Empirical antimicrobial therapy is the same for acute and chronic osteomyelitis,
but necrotic bone must often be removed for cure of chronic osteomyelitis.If
complete debridement is not possible, long-term suppressive antimicrobials may
be needed.Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.
The most important pathogens are S. aureus and streptococci.Gram negative
bacilli are common pathogens in osteomyelitis associated with diabetic foot
Recommend Orthopedic, Neurosurgery (for spine or skull osteomyelitis), Podiatry
(for foot infections), and Infectious Diseases consults.
Treat for 4 to 6 weeks.Do not place a long-term intravascular access device
(e.g. a PICC line) until it is clear the patient will need long-term intravenous
therapy.Consult Infectious Diseases or Orthopedic Surgery for more
>>For patients with infections associated with prosthetic materials see
>>For patients with sternal infection associated with chest surgery, refer to
mediastinitis, under Lungs and Mediastinum, in the Inpatient Antimicrobial

Contents.Text: MAI colonization in patients with chronic lung disease is common. These
patients should not be treated with antimicrobials.
Occasionally, MAI causes pulmonary disease in patients who are not
immunosuppressed. Diagnosis and management are complex. Consult Infectious
MAI causes systemic disease commonly in patients with HIV/AIDS. Most of these
cases do not involve the lungs. After treatment, long-term prophylaxis is

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) refers to bacterial infection of the upper
female reproductive tract. Likely bacterial pathogens include Neisseria
gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, anaerobes, enteric Gram-negative rods, and
Streptococcus agalactiae. PID should be considered in sexually active women
with pelvic tenderness and signs of lower genital tract inflammation. Signs and
symptoms may be mild or non-specific, and providers should have a low threshold
to initiate treatment. All women who are diagnosed with acute PID should be
tested for N. gonorrohoeae, C. trachomatis, and HIV. Male sex partners of
patients with PID should be examined and treated (see below) if they had sexual
contact within the 60 days before onset of the patient's symptoms.
Judge severity of infection based on clinical signs and symptoms, including
blood pressure, pulse, mental status, and degree of fever.
Treatment for mild to moderate disease
days ($) [DI] < OPTIONAL > metronidazole 500 mg PO BID ($) [DI]
For patients who cannot take ceftriaxone and doxycycline, call ID

Peritonitis associated with peritoneal dialysis usually presents with abdominal
pain, fever, nausea or vomiting, and cloudy effluent. The leukocyte
concentration is greater than 100 cells/microliter of dialysate, with more than
Obtain Gram stain, culture, and cell count with differential of dialysate before
antimicrobials are given. Nephrology consultation is essential. If cultures
show Gram-negative or mixed bacterial infection, a gastrointestinal tract
infectious source is more likely. Gram-positive organisms like staphylococci
usually result from external contamination. Fungal peritonitis is rare and
**Antimicrobial recommendations are for empirical therapy only. Regimens should
be tailored according to patient response and microbiology results in
consultation with Nephrology and/or Infectious Diseases for more information.
To prevent catheter occlusion by turbid dialysate, add 1,000 units of heparin
per dialysis bag each day until one day after the dialysate is clear.
If vancomycin is used, trough serum concentrations should be kept above 15
mcg/ml to ensure adequate intraperitoneal levels. Usually vancomycin must be
given every 3 to 7 days. Contact Nephrology and/or Pharmacy for more
Antifungal prophylaxis may be used for the duration of antimicrobial therapy to
possibly reduce the risk of fungal peritonitis.
If heparin PD therapy is needed in addition to antimicrobial therapy, click on
Duration of therapy depends on the pathogen identified. Treat staphylococcal and
streptococcal infections for 2 weeks and all other gram-positive infections for
3 weeks. In patients who have Staphylococcus isolated and had a previous
All antimicrobials below are administered via peritoneal dialysate bag over 6

Contents.Text: Periodontal disease, including gingivitis and periodontitis, may progress into
more severe disease or cause hematogenous spreading of bacteria if left
untreated. All patients with periodontal disease should be referred to the
dental service for assessment and direction of treatment. In the presence of
gingivitis, the most commonly isolated subgingival flora includes Prevotella
intermedia, Capnocytophaga spp, Finegoldia magna and Peptostreptococcus. In the
presence of periodontitis, flora increases in complexity to most commonly
include Porphyromonas gingivalis, P. intermedia, Aggregatibacter
actinomycetemcomitans, Tanneralla forsythensis and Treponema denticola.
Non-severe periodontitis or acute simple gingivitis treatment
Severe periodontitis or acute complicated gingivitis (ulceration, rapidly
advancing disease, severe pain, patients with immunocompromising conditions)

Immunity conferred by pertussis vaccine wanes after about 10 years. The first 1
to 2 weeks of disease resembles viral upper respiratory infection. After this,
the characteristic cough with whoop is present for 1 to 6 weeks, followed by a
2 to 3 week period of gradual resolution.

Contents.Text: Diagnosis and treatment are complex, consult Infectious Diseases in all cases.
Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly termed Pneumocystis carinii) in an ubiquitious
organism that causes disease in people with compromised cell-mediated immunity.
Disease is exceedingly rare in people with intact host defenses. Pneumonia is
the usual manifestation but P. jirovecii can infect extrapulmonary sites,
especially in patients who have been receiving prophylaxis with aerosolized
pentanmidine. P. jirovecii disease occurs most commonly in people with AIDS and
The abbreviation PCP is often used for Pneumocystis pneumonia. It was derived
from the old species name, Pneumocystis carinii.
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ) is the treatment of choice for P.
jirovecii disease, including disease that occurs despite TMP-SMZ prophylaxis.
Corticosteriods should be prescribed for patients with AIDS and P. jirovecii

Contents.Text: Indications for primary prophylaxis of P. jirovecii include:
1) HIV/AIDS patients with CD4 count <200 cells/microliter
2) Hematopoietic or organ transplantation patients during immunosuppression
3) Patients receiving Alemtuzumab, temozolomide or fludarabine
4) Patients receiving >/= 20mg equivalent of prednisone per day for over 1 month
5) Patients with acute lymphocytic leukemia, rheumatologic disease receiving
immunosuppressive therapy and certain primary immunodeficiencies (e.g. severe
combined immunodeficiency, idiopathic CD4 T-lymphocytopenia, hyper-IgM syndrome)
Dose and duration of prophylaxis varies with the indication. Please contact
Infectious Diseases or Hematology/Oncology for more information.
Prophylaxis should be discontinued when host defenses are restored. In persons
with AIDS on highly active antiretroviral therapy, Prophylaxis should be
discontinued when the CD4 cell concentrations remain over 200 cells/microliter
for 3-6 months in patients, except that prophylaxis should be continued for
life in those who have had P. jirovecii disease.

Contact otolaryngology or ophthalmology immediately for urgent surgical

pathogen can be identified from the drainage fluid.

complicated orbital cellulitis (severe ethmoid sinusitis and bony destruction of
sinus) should be treated for at least 4 weeks.

RISK FACTORS FOR ANTIMICROBIALS DURING PREGNANCY
The FDA amended its rules in 2015 concerning the Pregnancy, Labor and delivery,
and Nursing mothers subsections of the Use in Specific Populations section of
product labeling. Pregnancy categories A, B, C, D, and X have been removed.
Drugs approved after June 30 will use the new format immediately, while drugs
approved after June 30, 2001 will be phased in gradually.
See Sanford Guide for comprehensive antimicrobial pregnancy risk and lactation
Risk Factors (A,B,C,D,X) were assigned to all drugs, based on the
level of risk the drug poses to the fetus. Risk Factors were designed to
help the clinician quickly classify a drug for use during pregnancy. They
do not refer to breastfeeding risk. The definitions of the Risk Factors
are those used by the FDA.
A Controlled studies show no risk
Adequate, well-controlled studies in pregnant women
have failed to demonstrate risk to the fetus.
B No evidence of risk in humans
Either animal findings show risk (but human
findings do not) or, if no adequate human studies
have been done, animal findings are negative.
C Risk cannot be ruled out
Human studies are lacking and animal studies
are either positive for fetal risk or lacking
as well. However, potential benefits may
Investigational or postmarketing data show risk
to fetus. Nevertheless, potential benefits may
Studies in animals or humans, or investigational
or postmarketing reports have shown fetal risk
which clearly outweighs any possible benefit to

Contents.Text: PREVENTION OF FUNGAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Antifungal chemoprophylaxis is often given to patients undergoing induction
chemotherapy for acute leukemia expected to have profound neutropenia (less than
100 neutrophils and bands per milliliter) for more than 10 days and for patients
receiving allogeneic stem cell transplantation.For most other patients the
expected benefits do not outweigh the risks of adverse effects and selection of
Antifungal is usually given until the absolute neutrophil concentration
increases to more than 500 cells/microliter in patients undergoing induction
chemotherapy for leukemia.Duration is 100 days for patients undergoing stem
cell transplantation.Some physicians continue prevention after 100 days if
corticosteroids are part of the immunosuppressive regimen.
Recommend posaconazole prophylaxis for patients with Acute Myeloid Leukemia.
Contact Hematology Oncology or Infectious Disease for more information.
Patients who have had invasive fungal infection in the recent past and who are
about to become neutropenic may require chemoprophylaxis.Contact Hematology-
Oncology or Infectious Diseases for more information.

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ABX PROCED FOR INFECTED SKIN OUTPATIENT
Contents.Text: Patients undergoing procedures for infected skin, skin structures, or infected
Bacteremia occurs several times a day during daily activities like eating and
brushing teeth and rarely results in endocarditis, even in people with abnormal
valves.While bacteremia might occur following dental or other procedures, most
cases of endocarditis are from the millions more episodes of transient
bacteremia a person experiences per year from ordinary daily activities.There
is no evidence that antimicrobial prophylaxis prevents endocarditis after
procedures.The best available evidence suggests that prophylactic
antimicrobials confer more risks than benefits in most situations.A decision
about whether to administer antimicrobial prophylaxis should be based on both
the risk of endocarditis conferred by the patient's cardiac defect and the risk
of bacteremia from a planned dental or surgical procedure.
Minneapolis VAHCS SOP antimicrobial prophylaxis for dental surgery:
Determine the need for prophylaxis through the 2-step process outlined
Step 1.Assess the risk of endocarditis for your patient
Prophylaxis is recommended if a patient has any of the following conditions:
oProsthetic cardiac valve or material including: Presence of cardiac
prosthetic valve, transcatheter implantation of prosthetic valves (e.g. TAVR
cardiac valve repair with devices (e.g. annuloplasty, rings, or clips), left
ventricular assist devices or implantable heart
oCertain specific congenital heart conditions - refer to the full SOP
(link above) or consult Cardiology for more detailed recommendations
oCardiac transplant that develops a problem in the heart valve
Step 2.Assess the risk of bacteremia from the planned procedure
Prophylaxis is indicated for these procedures:
oAll dental procedures that involve manipulation of gingival tissue or the
periapical region of teeth or perforation of the oral mucosa.
oProcedures on the respiratory tract that involve incision or biopsy of the
respiratory mucosa, such as tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy. Prophylaxis is
recommended for bronchoscopy when it involves incision of the respiratory
oProcedures that involve incision through infected skin, skin structures, or
oDermatologic procedures that breach the oral mucosa.

Contents.Text: Give a single dose of tetanus-diphtheria acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) in

Household contacts with symptomatic coughing should be treated as if they have
pertussis. Consult Infectious Diseases (outpatient) for all suspected cases of
CDC recommends postexposure prophylaxis in household contacts within 21 days
after exposure to pertussis regardless of immunization history. Non-household
contacts who are at high risk of severe illness or who have close contact with
high risk individuals should receive post exposure prophylaxis within 21 days of
exposure. Those at high risk of severe illness are infants less than one year of
age, women in third trimester of pregnancy and those with preexisting health
conditions that may be exacerbated by pertussis (e.g. immunosuppressed and
asthmatic individuals). A single dose of Tdap should be administered in those
who are not up to date.

Contents.Text: INFECTIONS IN BONE OR JOINT PROSTHESES
Common important pathogens include coagulase-negative staphylococci,
Staphylococcus aureus, streptococci, enterococci, and gram negative bacilli.
Obtain material for gram stain and culture and base antimicrobial therapy on
results of Gram stain. Blood, joint fluid, and affected tissue and/or bone are
ideal specimens to culture. Sinus tracts are often colonized and isolates from
drainage may not be pathogens. If Staphylococcus aureus is present,it is likely
to be a pathogen in the bone.
Acute infections can often be cured with debridement with joint retention
followed by antimicrobials. Infections with duration of symptoms greater then 3
weeks or infection within 4 weeks of implantation require one or two stage
remimplantation. Cases that are inoperable can be managed with long-term
suppressive antimicrobial therapy or joint removal without replacement depending
on patient's condition. Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.
Infectious Disease and Orthopedics consultations are essential.
Empirical Therapy Before a Pathogen is Identified is Not Recommended.
If patient has sepsis or is otherwise unstable, empiric treatment before culture
results are obtained may be justified.
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for IV treatment options.
Up-to-Date Article: Prosthetic Joint Infections: Treatment
Osmon et al, Clinical Infectious Diseases (2013) 56.1, e1-25

The presence of nits on a hair shaft, especially when they are located more
than 6 mm from the skin, does NOT indicate active infestation.Nits may remain
present for months after successful treatment.
Household contacts and persons who may have come into contact with personal
belongings of an infested individual should be examined for evidence of lice
and discarded or cleaned if contaminated.

Contents.Text: Features of pyelonephritis include fever/other signs of systemic infection,
flank pain, costovertebral tenderness, and pelvic or perianal pain in men. Most
cases are caused by Escherichia coli. Resistant organisms, such as Enterococcus
and Pseudomonas, are more likely if the patient is elderly, has been in the
hospital for more than 48 hours, or received a course of antibiotics.
Obtain a urine culture, urine Gram-stain, and blood culture immediately to guide
Drugs active against enterococci (ampicillin, piperacillin) or staphylococci
needn't be used if Gram-negative bacilli predominate on the smear. Broad
spectrum antimicrobials are needed if patient is at risk of having a multi-drug
Judge severity of infection based on clinical signs and symptoms, including
blood pressure, pulse, mental status, white blood count, and degree of fever.
Oral regimens are preferred over IV if severity is mild or moderate and patient
can tolerate oral antibiotics. In patients with severe or persistent disease,
new renal failure, or suspected urinary obstruction, obtain a renal ultrasound
to rule out obstruction or other complicating condition. Consult urology if
When patients who require paraenteral therapy are afebrile, clinically stable,
and can take oral medication, convert to oral therapy based on the
identification and susceptibility of the isolate.
Treat for 7 to 14 days. In patients with a mild infection and a quick clinical
response, 7 days of treatment may be adequate. A longer duration may be required
in severe infection, resistant organisms, presence of obstruction, underlying
renal disease, immunosuppression, neurologic or structural abnormality, and men
in some cases. A 7-day course of ciprofloxacin has been shown to be as effective
Oral treatment after single dose of ceftriaxone IV above:

S. aureus is an uncommon urinary tract pathogen and presence in the urine may be
due to hematogenous seeding from another site. Blood cultures are indicated to
rule out bacteremia in patients who have S. aureus isolated from the urine.
Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.

Contents.Text: REACTIVATION OF PRIMARY INFECTION (ZOSTER OR SHINGLES)
Zoster represents reactivation of varicella-zoster virus. After primary
infection, virus remains latent in the sensory dorsal root ganglia.
Reactivation syndrome is characterized by painful, unilateral, vesicular,
Vaccinate all adults greater than or equal to 50 years of age with the
recombinant zoster vaccine regardless of past episode or receipt of the live
Give recombinant zoster vaccine x2, 2nd dose 2-6 months after the first
Treatment is not beneficial, none is recommended.
Treatment with antivirals can shorten duration of pain and rash in patients over
50 years old. Treatment must be started within 72 hours of onset.
There is evidence that addition of corticosteroids to antiviral
therapy decreases pain and duration of rash and improves quality of life
modestly during the acute shingles episode. Corticosteroids do not decrease the
incidence of post-herpetic neuralgia. Some authorities recommend addition of
corticosteroid therapy to antiviral therapy for patients over age 50 years.
Corticosteroids are not recommended for patients at greater risk for steroid
toxicities (e.g., insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, hypertension, peptic
ulcer disease) or for immunocompromised patients.
Immunocompromised patients at increased risk for complications of VZV disease
include: patients with malignancy, current immunosuppressive therapy, or HIV
infection. Treatment with antivirals shortens duration of symptoms and reduces
incidence of complications. In immunocompromised patients, treatment is
recommended to be started at any point during an active infection.

Contents.Text: Retinitis is a subset of uveitis, is rare in immunocompetent people: in these
individuals it is usually caused by varicella-zoster virus (VZV) or herpes
simplex virus (HSV). Retinitis is more common in immunocompromised patients and
cytomegalovirus being the most common pathogen in these patients. Other
retinitis pathogens include Toxoplasma gondii, Bartonella henselae, Histoplasma
capsulatum, and Treponema pallidum. In most cases, patients have other
neurological symptoms or signs.Patients with candidemia may present with 1-3
mm white punctate retinal lesions called cotton-wool spots. These may only be
visible on fundus examination. Treatment of candidal retinitisis systemic
antifungal therapy. Consult Ophthalmology, Infectious Diseases, or Neurology for
VZV and HSV cause nearly all cases of acute retinal necrosis (ARN), with a small
number being caused by cytomegalovirus. ARN is a rapidly progressing retinitis
that occurs primarily in immunocompetent people and can cause vision loss.
Treatment with intravenous acyclovir or valacyclovir is essential to halt
Ophthalmology and Infectious Diseases consultation is essential
Treatment of Non-viral Retinitis or ARN
Refer to specific pathogen treatment recommendations of the CDSS to treat
Treatment of Retinitis or ARN due to CMV:
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for parenteral therapy
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for parenteral therapy
Treatment of VZV and HSV Acute Retinal Necrosis
Ophthalmologist involvement is essential for treatment including
corticosteroids, vitrectomy, or laser therapy. Intravitreal foscarnet in
addition to a systemic antiviral may provide added therapeutic efficacy.
Treat with intravenous therapy for a minimum of 7 days until disease has
stabilized then treat with or therapy for a minimum of 6 weeks
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for parenteral therapy

Contents.Text: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever is a tick-borne, potentially life-threatening
rickettsial disease. The highest incidence in the United States is in the
Southeastern and South-central states. Clinical diagnosis include fever in
endemic area, known or possible tick bite, with or without rash. Rash typically
spreads from the extremities to the trunk.
Diagnosis is difficult, consult Infectious Diseases for assistance.
Consider empirical therapy with doxycycline for a patient with an undiagnosed
febrile illness and relevant tick exposure.
Sanford keyword: Rocky mountain spotted fever

Contents.Text: Scabies is an infestation of the skin by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei.
It is transmitted by skin to skin contact. Outbreaks occur in nursing
homes, day care centers, and residential institutions.Scabies is highly
contagious and meticulous infection control is needed.
Treatment is a single application of permethrin cream.Some experts recommend
a second application 7-10 days after the first application if the patient is
still symptomatic or if live mites are found at that time.Contact Dermatology
or Infectious Diseases for more information.
Treat family members and other close contacts to prevent spread and recurrence.
Repeat application 7-10 days after the first application if patient is still
experiencing symptoms, or if lives mites are found.

otherwise healthy individuals with intravenous therapy for part of the
course and then switch to oral therapy. Other clinicians treat mild cases
with oral therapy for the entire course. Drug selection should be based on
microbiological results. Close clinical follow-up is needed for all cases.

Contents.Text: HIV Post-Exposure Prophylaxis Non-Occupational (Blood/Body Fluids) Outpatient
Trichomonas Vaginitis, Urethritis and Male Sex Partners
that could result in HIV exposure. Recommendation is for the provider to
discuss with the patient Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) to reduce risk of
HIV acquisition.If the patient is interested, the provider should place a
consult to MRTC clinic for further discussion and evaluation for PrEP.
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (or PrEP) is a way for people who do not have
HIV but who are at high risk of getting HIV to prevent HIV infection by
taking a pill every day. When someone is exposed to HIV through sex or
injection drug use, these medicines can work to keep the virus from
Per CDC, when taken daily PrEP is highly effective for preventing HIV. Studies
have shown that PrEP reduces the risk of getting HIV from sex by about
99% when taken daily. PrEP is much less effective if not taken consistently.
As PrEP only protects against HIV, condoms are important for the protection
against other STIs. Condoms are also an important prevention strategy
if PrEP is not taken consistently.

Contents.Text: SMALL PLEOMORPHIC BACILLI IN AEROBIC BOTTLE
Small pleomorphic bacilli in aerobic bottle are usually diphtheroids. These are
usually contaminants. Uncommonly such organisms prove to be Listeria
monocytogenes, which when present in a blood culture is likely a pathogen.
Listeria is more likely in patients with impaired cell-mediated immunity,
pregnant women, elderly and patients on immunosuppressive therapy for
Empirical treatment if there is a strong suspicion of listeria
Refer to Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for intravenous treatment options
Empirical treatment if therapy is indicated and listeria is not suspected
Refer to Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for intravenous treatment options

Functional or Anatomical Asplenia Vaccine & Antibiotic Prophylaxis Guideline
Following a splenectomy there is considerably increased risk of developing
septicemia from invasive encapsulated organisms, namely Streptococcus pneumonia,
Haemophilus inluenza type b and meningococcus. Key measures to prevent
such infections include education, vaccination, prophylactic antimicrobial
therapy in selected patients, and early empirical therapy for febrile
epsisodes. It is critically important to educate patients regarding the
lifelong risk of postsplenectomy sepsis, the importance of vaccinations,
and the need for urgent action in response to a febrile episode.
Management of an Episode of Fever in an Asplenic Patient
Routine vaccines should be up to date.
See CDSS Immunization section to order, if needed.
Ideally splenectomy vaccinations should be given 10 to 12 weeks before
elective splenectomy.Where this is not possible they can be given up to
two weeks before or at least two weeks post-splenectomy.
Use of Antibiotic Prophylaxis for Asplenia:
Use of antibiotic prophylaxis, in addition to vaccination, further reduces
the risk of infection and poor outcomes.
Daily Antibiotic Prophylaxis: (in addition to emergency supply)
Emergency Supply Empiric Abx for Fever or Other Signs of Systemic Infection:
Up-to-Date: Prevention of infection in patients with impaired splenic function

Contents.Text: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) presents with severe skin
blistering and exfoliation resulting from toxins produced by Staphylococcus
aureus.SSSS is usually found in children and rarely in older adults.Obtain
a skin biopsy to differentiate between SSSS and toxic epidermal necrolysis.
Initiate anti-staphylococcal therapy and obtain cultures and susceptibilities.
If cultures reveal methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), change
to nafcillin or cefazolin for better antimicrobial activity.
Sanford keyword: Staph. Scalded skin syndrome
Mandell chapter: The acutely ill patient with fever and rash

Contents.Text: Onychomycosis is a fungal infection of the nail that presents with yellow,
thick, or crumbling nails. Obtain a fungal stain of nail sample prior to
initiating treatment. Using large nail clippers, remove as much of the
unattached dystrophic nail as possible. Place the piece of clipped nail plate
in formalin jar and send to pathology for fungal stain (PAS). Treatment should
only be initiated if stain is positive for fungal elements. Fungal culture is
Cure is unlikely if the entire nail is involved, or if a portion of the lunula
is involved. Sometimes after treatment the fungus is cured, but the nail
still does not appear normal because once nail dystrophy occurs, that
Systemic therapy is most likely to achieve a cure, especially with more nail
involvement. If <25% involvement topical therapy may be considered. If
>50-75% involvement systemic therapy should be considered.
Terbinafine works about 70% of the time to cure the fungus, and reinfection
is common, so many patients will need to do more than one course
of treatment.Fluconazole pulse dosing response rate is approximately 50%.
May consider retreatment with oral therapy after one year.
Recommend Dermatology Consult for retreatment after failure of 2 courses of

Contents.Text: On December 8, 2021 the FDA issued an EUA for AstraZeneca's Evusheld
(tixagevimab co-packaged with cilgavimab) for the pre-exposure prophylaxis
(prevention) of COVID-19 in certain adult and pediatric patients.
The product is only authorized for those individuals who are not currently
infected with SARS-CoV-2 virus and who have not recently been exposed to an
individual infected with SARS-CoV-2. The authorization also requires that
-moderate to severely compromised immune systems due to a medical condition or
or due to taking immunosuppressive medications or treatments and may not
mount an adequate immune response to COVID-19 vaccination (examples of such
medical conditions or treatments can be found in the fact sheet for health
care providers) [see link top of page]
-a history of severe adverse reactions to a COVID-19 vaccine and/or component(s)
of those vaccines, therefore vaccination with an available COVID-19 vaccine,
according to the approved or authorized schedule, is not recommended.
-One dose of Evusheld, administered as two separate consecutive intramuscular
injections (one injection per monoclonal antibody, given in immediate
succession), reduces the risk of developing COVID-19 for six months.
-Evusheld is NOT authorized for the treatment of COVID-19 or for post-exposure
-Pre-exposure prevention with Evusheld is not a substitute for vaccination in
in individuals for whom COVID-19 vaccination is recommended.
Monoclonal antibodies are laboratory-made proteins that mimic the immune
system's ability to fight off harmful pathogens such as viruses. Tixagevimab and
cilgavimab are long-acting monoclonal antibodies that are specifically directed
against the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, designed to block the virus' attachment
and entry into human cells. Tigagevimab and cilgavimab bind to different,
non-overlapping sites on the spike protein of the virus.
Emergency Use Authorization (EUA): Tixagevimab plus Cilgavimab (EVUSHELD)
Tixagevimab plus Cilgavimab combination is available via FDA Emergency Use
Authorization (EUA) for pre-exposure prophylaxis for COVID-19 for patients
that meet specific criteria. They are not FDA approved drugs.
There are no adequate, approved and available alternatives to Evusheld
for the pre-exposure prevention of COVID-19 in the authorized population.
-In patients with prior COVID-19 vaccination, at least 2 weeks are required
between the vaccination and the administration of Evusheld.
**PBM EUA Criteria to be completed on web link:
Answer to ALL of the following statements should be YES for administration:
2)Patient has no known recent exposure to an individual infected with SARS-CoV-2
1)Patient has no symptoms consistent with COVID-19, or if any symptoms, has a
a documented negative SARS-CoV-2 test within 72 hours prior to administration
3)Patient has moderate to severe immunocompromise per the EUA definition or

Contents.Text: Acute non-bloody diarrhea (< 14 days of symptoms)
Most cases are mild and self-limited. Reserve antimicrobial therapy for
patients who have severe traveler's diarrhea: pus, or mucus in stool, fever, or
Bloody diarrhea can represent hemorrhagic colitis or dysentery. Antimicrobial
therapy and antimotility agents are not recommended in most patients with bloody
diarrhea due to an increased risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome when using these
agents. Obtain a stool sample for enteric pathogen PCR testing and reserve
antimicrobial and antimotility agent treatment until results are known. Enteric
pathogen PCR testing results are reported within 2 hours between 7am and 11pm.
For more information on when an antimicrobial is indicated or if the patient has
severe/life threatening diarrhea or is immunocompromised, contact Infectious
Empiric antimicrobial treatment for non-bloody severe acute diarrhea
Primary treatment is hydration and electrolyte replacement. Empirical
antimicrobial therapy is not indicated. Attempt to make a diagnosis with, for
example, enteric pathogen PCR testing, Clostridium difficile testing in those
who used a PPI or were treated with antimicrobials in the last 8-12 weeks, and
endoscopy. If bloody diarrhea, fever, or abdominal pain/tenderness is present
the case should be evaluated by Gastroenterology and/or Infectious Diseases.
Mandell chapter: Nausea, Vomiting, and Noninflammatory Diarrhea

Contents.Text: Uncomplicated cystitis is defined as symptomatic bladder inflammation caused by
bacterial infections in people with structurally and neurogenically normal
urinary tract. Symptoms usually include dysuria, lower abdominal pain, and
urgency. Most cases of uncomplicated cystitis occur in pre-menopausal,
non-pregnant, sexually active young women and is commonly associated with
Enterobacteriaceae (e.g. E. coli and Klebsiella sp.) and occasionally S.
Cystitis is considered complicated when it occurs in pregnant women, people
with abnormalities of the urinary tract, immunocompromised individuals and those
who have persistent, recurrent, or relapsed infections, or treatment failure are
considered complicated. Diagnosis and treatment of complicated cystitis is
The presence of pyuria (>7 wbc/hpf) or positive leukocyte esterase, urine
nitrate, or urine bacteria is not a sufficient indication for antibiotic
treatment. Asymptomatic bacteriuria occurs in patients who have bacteria in the
urine with no symptoms of cystitis, and with few exceptions, should not be
treated. Diagnosis and treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria is further
The prevalence of antimicrobial resistance among bacteria associated with
uncomplicated cystitis has increased. A urine culture should be considered in a
patient who has had substantial involvement with healthcare or exposure to
antimicrobials. If a patient fails to respond to therapy, a urine culture should
For women with recurrent uncomplicated cystitis (2 episodes in 6 months or 3 or
more episodes in 12 months), suppressive therapy is indicated after infection is
eradicated and non-antimicrobial prevention methods, such as increased fluid
intake and avoiding spermicide, are considered. Consider consulting Women's
*Avoid trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole in the first and third trimesters

Treatment for chlamydial or non-gonococcal urethritis
URETHRITIS ASSOCIATED WITH SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES
The main differential in a person who presents with dysuria is between cystitis
and urethritis. Bacterial urethritis is more likely in people with mild
dysuria, onset over a few days, or recent sexual contact.
The two most common sexually transmitted urethritis pathogens are Neisseria
gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Nucleic acid amplification tests for
these pathogens are more sensitive than culture and should be used for patients
at risk for sexually transmitted urethritis.
For patients who have recently been treated for urethritis

Contents.Text: DRUG-DRUG INTERACTIONS BETWEEN ANTIMICROBIALS AND WARFARIN
Several antimicrobials will affect metabolism or the effect of
warfarin on a patient's clotting function. If possible, avoid using an
antimicrobial with a significant interaction with warfarin. If you
decide that an antimicrobial that interacts with warfarin is needed or
you stop an antimicrobial that could interact with warfarin, you
should determine the INR more frequently than usual and adjust dosage
accordingly. Instruct patients to inform their primary warfarin
provider whenever an antimicrobial is prescribed for them.
Antimicrobials can alter warfarin's anticoagulant effect by decreasing
intestinal synthesis or absorption of vitamin K or by affecting
distribution or metabolism of the vitamin. Some antimicrobials increase
Antimicrobials can decrease the rate of warfarin absorption, compete
with warfarin at sites of warfarin metabolism, induce warfarin
metabolic enzymes, or inhibit the function or synthesis warfarin
metabolic enzymes. Some antimicrobials displace warfarin from protein
Check for warfarin-antimicrobial interactions on Lexicomp:
